{{Redirect|Tian gong|other uses|Tiangong (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Chinese |title = '''Jade Emperor''' |pic = Jade Emperor. Ming Dynasty.jpg |piccap = Jade Emperor in a Ming Dynasty ink and color painting on silk, 16th century |l = Jade Emperor |p = Yù Huáng |c = 玉皇 |ci2 = <!--Cantonese IPA2 --> |h2 = <!--Hakka2 --> |poj2 = Gio̍k-tè <!-- Second alternative name --> |altname3 = |c3 = 天公 |l3 = Heavenly Grandfather |p3 = Tiān Gōng |mi3 = <!--Mandarin IPA3 --> |j3 = <!--Cantonese Jyutping3 --> |h3 = <!--Hakka3 --> |poj3 = Thiⁿ-kong <!-- Third alternative name --> |altname4 = <!--Third alternative name --> |c4 = 玉皇大帝 |l4 = August Emperor of Jade |p4 = Yù Huáng Dàdì |j4 = <!--Cantonese Jyutping4 --> |h4 = <!--Hakka4 --> |poj4 = Gio̍k-hông-tāi-tè }} The '''Jade Emperor''' ({{zh|c=玉皇|p=Yù Huáng}} or {{lang|zh|玉帝}}, ''{{transl|zh|Yù Dì}}'') in [[Chinese culture]], [[Chinese folk religion|traditional religions]] and [[Chinese mythology|myth]] is one of the representations of the [[Primordial Divinity (Tai Di)|first god]] ({{lang|zh|太帝}} ''{{transl|zh|tài dì}}''). In [[Taoism|Daoist theology]] he is the assistant of [[Yuanshi Tianzun]], who is one of the [[Three Pure Ones]], the three primordial emanations of the [[Tao]]. He is also the ''{{lang|vi|Cao Đài}}'' ("Highest Power") of [[Caodaism]] known as [[:vi:Ngọc Hoàng Thượng đế|Ngọc Hoàng Thượng đế]]. In [[Buddhist cosmology]] he is identified with [[Śakra (Buddhism)|Śakra]].<ref>[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=GgpkAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false A Simple Approach To Taoism]</ref> In [[Korean mythology]] he is known as [[Hwanin]].<ref>[https://books.google.com.au/books?id=awCJAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false The Annals of King T'aejo]</ref>
The Jade Emperor is known by many names, including Heavenly Grandfather ({{lang|zh|天公}}, ''{{transl|zh|Tiān Gōng}}''), which originally meant "Heavenly Duke", which is used by commoners; the Jade Lord; the Highest Emperor; Great Emperor of Jade ({{lang|zh|玉皇上帝}}, ''{{transl|zh|Yu Huang [[Shangdi]]}}'' or {{lang|zh|玉皇大帝}}, ''{{transl|zh|Yu Huang Dadi}}'').
==Chinese mythology== {{Taoism}} There are many stories in [[Chinese mythology]] involving the Jade Emperor.
===Origin=== It was said that the Jade Emperor was originally the crown prince of the kingdom of Pure Felicity and Majestic Heavenly Lights and Ornaments. At birth, he emitted a wondrous light that filled the entire kingdom. When he was young, he was kind, intelligent and wise. He devoted his entire childhood to helping the needy (the poor and suffering, the deserted and single, the hungry and disabled). Furthermore, he showed respect and benevolence to both men and creatures. After his father died, he ascended the throne. He made sure that everyone in his kingdom found peace and contentment. After that, he told his ministers that he wished to cultivate [[Tao]] on the Bright and Fragrant Cliff.
After 1,750 eons, each eon lasting for 129,600 years (360<sup>2</sup> years), he attained Golden Immortality. After another one hundred million years of cultivation, he finally became the Jade Emperor (using the given figures, this period before his becoming the Jade Emperor lasted for a total of about 226,800,000 years.)
===Vanquishing evil=== One of the myths describes how the Jade Emperor became the monarch of all the deities in heaven. It is one of the few myths in which the Jade Emperor really shows his might.
In the beginning of time, the earth was a very difficult place to live, much harsher than it is now. People had to deal with a variety of monstrous beings, and they didn’t have many gods to protect them; in addition, many powerful demons were defying the immortals of heaven. The Jade Emperor was an ordinary immortal who roamed the earth helping as many people as he could. He was saddened because his powers could only ease the suffering of humans. He retreated to a mountain cave to cultivate his Tao. He passed 3,200 trials, each trial lasting about 3 million years.
On earth at this time, a powerful, evil entity had the ambition to conquer the immortals and gods in heaven and proclaim sovereignty over the entire universe. This evil entity also went into retreat and meditation to expand its power, though later than the Jade Emperor did. He passed through 3,000 trials, each trial lasting about 3 million years. After its final trial, it felt confident that no one could defeat it. It re-entered the world and recruited an army of demons with the purpose of attacking heaven.
The immortals, being aware of the threat, gathered themselves and prepared for war. The gods were unable to stop the powerful demon and it defeated them all.
The Jade Emperor finished his cultivation during this war. When he was changing the land to make it more liveable for men and repelling a variety of monsters, he saw an evil glow radiating from heaven and knew something was amiss. He ascended and saw that the evil entity was too powerful to be stopped by the gods. He challenged it, and they fought. Mountains shook and rivers and seas toppled. Due to his deeper and wiser cultivation, his benevolence instead of his might, the Jade Emperor won the battle. After the evil entity was defeated, its army was scattered by the gods and immortals.
Because of his noble and benevolent deeds, the gods, immortals and humans proclaimed the Jade Emperor the supreme sovereign of all.
===Creation=== The world started with ''[[wuji (philosophy)|wuji]]'' ({{lang|zh|無極}}, nothingness) according to the [[Chinese creation myth]]. The Jade Emperor was the head of the pantheon, but not responsible for creation.
In another [[creation myth]], the Jade Emperor fashioned the first humans from clay and left them to harden in the sun. Rain deformed some of the figures, which gave rise to human sickness and physical abnormalities. (The most common alternative Chinese creation myth states that human beings were once fleas on the body of [[Pangu]].)
In another myth, [[Nüwa]] fashions men out of the mud from the Yellow River by hand. Those she made became the richer people of the earth. After getting lazy, she dipped her scarf into the mud and swung it around. The drops that fell from the scarf became the poorer humans.
===In ''The Journey to the West''=== {{Main|Journey to the West}}
In the popular novel by [[Wu Cheng'en]], the Jade Emperor is featured many times.
===''The Cowherd and the Weaver Girl''=== {{Main|The Cowherd and the Weaver Girl}} In another story{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}, popular throughout Asia and with many differing versions, the Jade Emperor has a daughter named '''Zhinü''' ({{zh|s=织女|t=織女|p=zhī nǚ}} or Chih'nü, literally: weaver girl). She is most often represented as responsible for weaving colorful clouds in the heaven. In some versions she is the Goddess Weaver, daughter of the Jade Emperor and the Celestial Queen Mother, who weaves the Silver River (known in the West as the [[Milky Way]]), which gives light to heaven and earth. In other versions, she is a seamstress who works for the Jade Emperor.
Every day Zhinü descended to earth with the aid of a magical robe to bathe. One day, a lowly cowherd named '''Niu Lang''' ({{zh|c=牛郎|p=niú láng}}) spotted Zhinü as she bathed in a stream. Niu Lang fell instantly in love with her and stole her magic robe which she had left on the bank of the stream, leaving her unable to escape back to Heaven. When Zhinü emerged from the water, Niu Lang grabbed her and carried her back to his home.
When the Jade Emperor heard of this matter, he was furious but unable to intercede, since in the meantime his daughter had fallen in love and married the cowherd. As time passed, Zhinü grew homesick and began to miss her father. One day, she came across a box containing her magic robe which her husband had hidden. She decided to visit her father back in Heaven, but once she returned, the Jade Emperor summoned a river to flow across the sky (the [[Milky Way]]), which Zhinü was unable to cross to return to her husband. The Emperor took pity on the young lovers, and so once a year on the seventh day of the seventh month of the [[lunar calendar]], he allows them to meet on a bridge over the river.
The story refers to [[constellation]]s in the night sky. Zhinü is the [[star]] [[Vega]] in the constellation of [[Lyra]] east of the Milky Way, and Niu Lang is the star [[Altair]] in the constellation of [[Aquila (constellation)|Aquila]] west of the Milky Way. Under the first quarter moon (7th day) of the seventh lunar month (around August), the lighting condition in the sky causes the Milky Way to appear dimmer, hence the story that the two lovers are no longer separated on that one particular day each year.
The seventh day of the seventh month of the lunar calendar is a holiday in China called [[Qixi Festival]], which is a day for young lovers much like [[Valentine's Day]] in the [[Western countries|West]]. In [[Japan]], it is called [[Tanabata]] (star day). In [[Korea]], it is called [[Chilseok]]. In [[Vietnam]], it is called Thất Tịch and if it rains on that day, it is said to be Zhinü crying tears of happiness for being reunited with her husband.
===The zodiac=== There are several stories as to how the twelve [[animal]]s of the [[Chinese zodiac]] were chosen. In one, the Jade Emperor, although having ruled Heaven and Earth justly and wisely for many years, had never had the time to actually visit the Earth personally. He grew curious as to what the creatures looked like. Thus, he asked all the animals to visit him in heaven. The cat, being the most handsome of all animals, asked his friend the [[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]] to wake him on the day they were to go to Heaven so he wouldn't oversleep. The [[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]], however, was worried that he would seem ugly compared to the cat, so he didn't wake the cat. Consequently, the cat missed the meeting with the Jade Emperor and was replaced by the [[Pig (zodiac)|Pig]]. The Jade Emperor was delighted with the animals and so decided to divide the years up amongst them. When the cat learned of what had happened, he was furious with the [[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]] and that, according to the story, is why cats and [[Rat (zodiac)|Rats]] are enemies to this day.
The [[Cat (zodiac)|Cat]] however, ''does'' have a place in the [[Vietnamese zodiac]], replacing the [[Rabbit (zodiac)|Rabbit]].
===''The Four Dragons''=== The Jade Emperor ordered the four dragons, the Yellow Dragon (representation of the [[Yellow River]]), the Long Dragon (representation of the [[Yangtze River]]), the Black Dragon (representation of the [[Amur River]]) and the Pearl Dragon (representation of the [[Pearl River (China)|Pearl River]]) by not making a rain since it was his own power to make rain for the crops to save. After 10 days, he did not make it rain because of his selfishness and he broke his own promise to the four dragons to make rain because people may die due to starvation. After the dragons let themselves to defy his orders to make rain without his permission, his men take these dragons to his kingdom and putting them each on a mountain until they die.
===His predecessor and successor=== The Jade Emperor was originally the assistant of the Divine Master of the Heavenly Origin, [[Yuanshi Tianzun]]. Yuanshi Tianzun is said to be the supreme beginning, the limitless and eternal creator of Heaven and Earth, who picked Yu-huang, or the Jade Emperor, as his personal successor.
The Jade Emperor will eventually be succeeded by the Heavenly Master of the Dawn of Jade of the Golden Door ({{lang|zh|金闕玉晨天尊}}).<ref>[http://www.bookhome.net/zhexue/zongjiao/djds.html 道教的神] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100519140532/http://www.bookhome.net/zhexue/zongjiao/djds.html |date=2010-05-19 }}</ref> The characters for both are stamped on the front of the arms of his throne.
In two folk [[Fuji (planchette writing)|automatic writing]] texts produced in 1925 and 1972, [[Guan Yu]] became the 18th Jade Emperor in about 1840 AD;<ref>[http://a3838838.myweb.hinet.net/02-07.zip 洞冥寶記]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>[http://www.cass.net.cn/zhuanti/y_guangong/f05_07.htm 關聖帝君受禪玉帝經略] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717152357/http://www.cass.net.cn/zhuanti/y_guangong/f05_07.htm |date=2011-07-17 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.boder.idv.tw/uchsj.htm 瑤池聖誌]</ref> however, some have disagreed that Guan Yu has succeeded, and thus the Jade Emperor and Guan Yu are often worshiped separately.<ref>[http://www.gotobr.org/RCCBRSUB/KnowingYiGuanDao/LetterToTendao.htm 寫給天道道親的一封信]</ref> In [[Lord of Universe Church|Tienti]] teaching, the reigning Jade Emperor has 55 predecessors.<ref> [http://tienti.info/v2/library/constitution/p040.html 教源──道統衍流 天帝立教道統衍流] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821121933/http://tienti.info/v2/library/constitution/p040.html |date=2008-08-21 }}</ref>
==Worship and festivals== [[File:Thni Kong Tnua, Air Itam, Penang.jpg|left|thumb|[[Thni Kong Tnua]] in [[Air Itam]], [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]] was specifically built in honour of the Jade Emperor.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.thestar.com.my/news/community/2006/10/17/temple-of-jade-emperor-god/ |title= Temple of Jade Emperor God - Community {{!}} The Star Online |website=www.thestar.com.my |access-date=2017-05-16}}</ref>]]<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Hellgreenback.jpg|thumb|265px|right|The Jade Emperor featured on the [[Hell Bank Notes|Hell Bank Note]].]] --> [[File:初九三星草湖玉尊宮拜天公.jpg|thumb|250px|The Jade Emperor Ritual at [[Yuzun Temple]] in [[Sanxing, Yilan|Sanxing]], [[Yilan_County,_Taiwan|Yilan]] of [[Taiwan]] on the Emperor's Birthday.]]
{{clear}}The Jade Emperor's Birthday ({{lang|zh|天公誕}}) is said to be the ninth day of the first lunar month.<ref name="lmr">{{cite web|url=http://taiwanpedia.culture.tw/en/content?ID=4414 |title=Jade Emperor |last=Lin Meirong |date=2011 |work=Encyclopedia of Taiwan |publisher=Council for Cultural Affairs |accessdate=12 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222074628/http://taiwanpedia.culture.tw/en/content?ID=4414 |archivedate=22 February 2014 |df= }}</ref> On this day Taoist [[temple]]s hold a Jade Emperor ritual ({{lang|zh|拜天公}}, ''{{transl|zh|bài Tiān Gōng}}'', literally "heaven worship") at which priests and laymen prostrate themselves, burn [[incense]] and make food offerings.
In the morning of this birthday, Chinese, Taiwanese as well as [[Hokkien]] and [[Peranakan]] [[Malaysian Chinese]] and [[Chinese Singaporeans|Singaporean Chinese]] who practice [[Buddhism]], [[Taoism]] and other traditional Chinese religions set up an altar table with 3 layers: one top (containing offertories of six vegetables ({{lang|zh|六齋}}), noodles, fruits, cakes, ''[[tangyuan (food)|tangyuan]]'', vegetable bowls, and unripe [[betel]], all decorated with paper lanterns) and two lower levels (containing the five sacrifices and wines) to honor the deities below the Jade Emperor.<ref name="lmr"/> The household then kneels three times and [[kowtow]]s nine times to pay homage and wish him a long life.<ref name="lmr"/>
In [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]], a focal point of the Jade Emperor's Birthday celebrations is [[Thni Kong Tnua]], which gained worldwide fame as one of the featured locations for ''[[The Amazing Race 16]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitpenang.gov.my/portal3/penang-tourism-news/1148-amazing-race-season-16-episode-8.html|title=Amazing Race Season 16, Episode 8|last=II|first=Administrator|website=www.visitpenang.gov.my|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-05-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507003422/http://www.visitpenang.gov.my/portal3/penang-tourism-news/1148-amazing-race-season-16-episode-8.html|archive-date=2018-05-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The temple, built in 1869, is located at the foot of [[Penang Hill]] at the [[Air Itam]] suburb near [[George Town, Penang|George Town]], [[Penang]]'s capital city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/community/2006/10/17/temple-of-jade-emperor-god/|title=Temple of Jade Emperor God - Community {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2017-05-16}}</ref> Aside from [[Thni Kong Tnua]], the Chew Jetty in the heart of [[George Town, Penang|George Town]] is another focal point of the Jade Emperor's Birthday celebrations; the festivities in this particular location was captured for a 2014 Malaysian film, [[The Journey (2014 Malaysian film)|''The Journey'']].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/metro/community/2017/02/06/aweinspiring-tribute-to-deity-hokkiens-go-all-out-to-celebrate-jade-emperor-gods-birthday-at-jetty-a/|title=Hokkiens go all out to celebrate Jade Emperor God’s birthday at jetty and temple - Community {{!}} The Star Online|website=www.thestar.com.my|access-date=2017-05-16}}</ref>
[[File:HK A Kung Ngam Village Road Temple 02.JPG|thumb|250px|Yuk Wong Po Tin in A Kung Ngam, Hong Kong.]]
Yuk Wong Kung Tin ({{lang|zh|玉皇宮殿}}) also known as Yuk Wong Po Tin ({{lang|zh|玉皇寶殿}}) is a temple in [[A Kung Ngam]], [[Hong Kong]], dedicated to the Jade Emperor. In the mid 19th century, people from [[Huizhou]] and [[Chaozhou]] mined stones in the hill for the development of the central urban area. They set up a shrine to worship Yuk Wong. At the beginning of the 20th century, the shrine was developed into a small [[temple]] and was renovated many times. The latest renovation was in 1992.<ref>[[Chinese Temples Committee]]: [http://www.ctc.org.hk/en/directcontrol/temple2.asp Yuk Wong Kung Din, A Kung Ngam]</ref>
==Toponyms== A crater on [[Saturn]]'s moon [[Rhea (moon)|Rhea]], discovered by [[Voyager 2]] spacecraft, is named after him.

{{Infobox LDS biography | name = Joseph Fielding Smith | image = Joseph Fielding Smith (presiding patriarch).jpg | image_size = 150px | alt = Photograph of Joseph Fielding Smith | birth_date = {{Birth date|1899|01|30}} | birth_place = [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|1964|08|29|1899|01|30}} | death_place = [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], United States | position_or_quorum1 = [[Presiding Patriarch|Patriarch to the Church]] | called_by1 = [[Heber J. Grant]] | start_date1 = {{death date and age|1942|09|17|1899|01|30}} | end_date1 = {{death date and age|1946|10|06|1899|01|30}} | end_reason1 = Released for reasons of "ill health" amid accusations of homosexual affairs | portals = LDS}} '''Joseph Fielding Smith''' (January 30, 1899 – August 29, 1964) was [[Presiding Patriarch]] and a [[general authority]] of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church) from 1942 until 1946.
Smith was born in [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]], the son of LDS Church [[apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostle]] [[Hyrum M. Smith]] and Ida Elizabeth Bowman. He went to school at the [[University of Utah]], where he majored in Theater. In 1929, he married Ruth Pingree.<ref>[http://www.ourfamilyhistories.org/familygroup.php?familyID=F77541&tree=00 Family: Joseph Fielding Smith/Ruth Pingree]. OurFamilyHistories.org</ref> Together they had seven children, Ruth, Ida, R.P. "Joe", Denis, Lynne, Hyrum, and Pauline.<ref>[https://archive.is/20120723135650/http://www.codyenterprise.com/articles/2007/05/10/obituaries/april_2004/obit959-1084.txt Lynne Esther Smith Partridge],{{Dead link|date=February 2011}} ''Cody Enterprise'' ([[Cody, Wyoming]])</ref>
==Patriarch to the Church== At the time of his calling to the patriarchate, Smith was a member of the church's [[Young Men (organization)|Mutual Improvement Association]] General Board, head of the Speech Department at the University of Utah (though he did not hold a Ph.D.), and was also president of the National Speech Association.<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" /> His calling as patriarch filled a vacancy that had lasted just over ten years, and his selection for the office has been seen by some as a departure from the expected line of patriarchal succession from father to his eldest son in good standing with the church.<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" /> Some sources suggest this move came during a time when some members of the church's [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]] and [[Quorum of the Twelve Apostles (LDS Church)|Quorum of the Twelve Apostles]] were attempting to move away from the rule of primogeniture in selecting the presiding patriarch, giving church leaders the ability to pass over unsuitable candidates who would otherwise inherit the office somewhat automatically.<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" /> Smith's official title was "Patriarch to the Church," in place of the previous style of "Patriarch over the Church" or "Presiding Patriarch," a change which was also accompanied by a reduction in the scope of the duties of the office; Smith was not permitted to ordain or formally supervise local stake patriarchs.<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" />
==Homosexual affairs==
At the age of 43, Smith was ordained a [[High priest (Mormonism)|high priest]] and Patriarch to the Church on October 8, 1942, by [[President of the Church (LDS Church)|church president]] [[Heber J. Grant]]. He served only four years before it was reported by the church that he had requested to be released from his position. His request was granted by church president [[George Albert Smith]] on October 6, 1946, with the church announcing that Smith was released for reasons of "ill health."<ref>"Patriarch to the Church: Released from Duties", ''[[Improvement Era]]'' '''49''' (November 1946) pp. 685, 708.</ref> In 1946 it had been discovered that the patriarch was involved in several [[Homosexuality|homosexual]] affairs, including two in the 1920s while employed at the [[University of Utah]] (with student Norval Service<ref>{{cite web|last1=Salinas|first1=Hugo|title=Queer Mormons of the 19th Century|url=http://affirmation.org/resources/books-films-plays-television/books-articles/queer-mormons-of-the-19th-century/|website=affirmation.org|publisher=Affirmation|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> and a drama department colleague named Wallace A. G.),<ref>{{cite web|last1=O'Donovan|first1=Connell|last2=Quinn|first2=D. Michael|title=Chronology of Events on Patriarch Joseph Fielding Smith’s Homosexuality|url=http://www.affirmation.org/memorial/joseph_fielding_smith.shtml|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122080551/http://www.affirmation.org/memorial/joseph_fielding_smith.shtml|archivedate=22 January 2010|website=affirmation.org|publisher=Affirmation|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> and one while serving as presiding patriarch in the 1940s (with 21-year-old [[U.S. Navy]] sailor<ref>{{cite web|title=Book on LDS Patriarchal Blessings Published|url=http://signaturebooks.com/book-on-lds-patriarchal-blessings-published/|website=signaturebooks.com|publisher=Signature Books Publishing|accessdate=23 February 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223213132/http://signaturebooks.com/book-on-lds-patriarchal-blessings-published/|archivedate=23 February 2017|df=}}</ref> Byram Dow Browning<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gibson|first1=Doug|title=Remember that Gay Mormon Patriarch?|url=http://www.realclearreligion.org/2012/04/18/remember_that_gay_mormon_patriarch_247346.html|website=realclearreligion.org|publisher=Real Clear Religion|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref> who was also a Latter-day Saint).<ref>{{cite book |last= Quinn |first= D. Michael |authorlink= D. Michael Quinn |title= Same-Sex Dynamics among Nineteenth-Century Americans: A Mormon Example |location= Urbana |publisher= [[University of Illinois Press]] |year= 2001 |isbn= 978-0-252-06958-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UXVj398JvnsC&pg=PA388&lpg=PA388&dq=homosexual+joseph+fielding+smith+patriarch&source=bl&ots=WNDRHK7KCG&sig=RDXi1FM4Z3thoBiFox3TG6xsVsA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiMtrmC3KXSAhVkHGMKHYy3BRg4ChDoAQgwMAQ#v=onepage&q=homosexual%20joseph%20fielding%20smith%20patriarch&f=false|pages= 369–371}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Whitefield|first1=Jim|title=The Mormon Delusion: The Secret Truth Withheld from 13 Million Mormons|date=21 May 2009|publisher=Lulu|isbn=1409278859|pages=261–262|edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RVTDAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA262&lpg=PA262&dq=gay+mormon+patriarch&source=bl&ots=q4d5QRugb6&sig=KqSU4RZJ2fcghW7NPbW9GvkDi8I&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwia0qnh26XSAhVDz2MKHVJ4D8o4ChDoAQgpMAI#v=onepage&q=gay%20mormon%20patriarch&f=false|accessdate=23 February 2017}}</ref><ref name="Bates Lost Legacy">{{cite book|last1=Bates|first1=Irene M.|last2=Smith | first2=E. Gary|title=Lost legacy: The Mormon office of presiding patriarch|date=1996|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Champaign, IL|isbn=0252021630|edition=1}}</ref> Church president [[George Albert Smith]] described the scandal as "a pitiable case" and "a sad happening" in his diary, describing himself as "heartsick" and as having a "restless night" in conjunction with the events and the necessity of releasing the patriarch.<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" />
==After release==
After being released, Smith took his family to [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lore|first1=Lambda|title=The birth of Mormon homophobia|url=http://gaysaltlake.com/news/2011/09/01/lambda-lore-the-birth-of-mormon-homophobia/|accessdate=23 February 2017|agency=Q Salt Lake Magazine|date=1 Sep 2011}}</ref> where he continued to raise his family and resumed his academic career as a teacher of English and drama.<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" /> For a time, Smith was not allowed to speak or hold any position in church,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Anderson|first1=J. Seth|title=LGBT Salt Lake: Images of Modern America|date=29 May 2017|publisher=Arcadia Publishing|isbn=9781467125857|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rlC1DgAAQBAJ&lpg=PT16&pg=PT25#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=16}}</ref> but no formal church disciplinary action was taken, and Smith was reportedly "treated with compassion."<ref>{{Citation |last1= James |first1= Rhett S. |authorlink1= Rhett S. James |last2= Mitton |first2= George L. |year= 1998 |title= A Response to D. Michael Quinn's Homosexual Distortion of Latter-day Saint History |url= http://maxwellinstitute.byu.edu/publications/review/?vol=10&num=1&id=280 |periodical= [[FARMS Review of Books]] |volume= 10 |issue= 1 |pages= 141–263 }}</ref><ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" /> Approximately a decade after his release as patriarch, Smith's stake president and bishop wrote to church president [[David O. McKay]] asking for restrictions on Smith to be lifted.<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" /> In 1957, after it was established he had forsaken his homosexual behavior, confessed to his wife, and sent a written confession to the First Presidency, Smith was again allowed to serve in the church.<ref name="O'Donovan JFS Chronology">{{cite web |url= http://www.connellodonovan.com/smith.html |title= Chronology of Events on Patriarch Joseph Fielding Smith’s Homosexuality |publisher= connellodonovan.com |first= Connell |last= O'Donovan }}</ref><ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" /> Shortly thereafter, Smith's wife Ruth wrote a letter to church president [[David O. McKay]] expressing her gratitude for the church's help, stating, "I know, better than anyone else, the trial our family has been to you and to the authorities."<ref name="O'Donovan JFS Chronology" /> From 1957 until his death, Smith served as a member of his stake's [[High council (Latter Day Saints)|high council]].<ref name="Bates Lost Legacy" />
Smith died and was buried in Salt Lake City, Utah.
Smith's grandson [[Jefferson Smith (politician)|Jefferson Smith]] served in the [[Oregon House of Representatives]] from 2008 to 2012.
Smith shares a name with his grandfather, [[Joseph F. Smith]], and his uncle, [[Joseph Fielding Smith]], both of whom served as [[Apostle (Mormonism)|apostles]] and later as [[President of the Church (LDS Church)|church presidents]].

{{Infobox university |name = Kepler College |image = File:Kepler College.jpg |caption = Kepler College Astrological Education |established = 2000 |type = Online certificate program, unaccredited |students = |city = [[Seattle, Washington]] |country = U.S. |former_names = Kepler College of Astrological Arts and Sciences |colors = |colours = |mascot = |website = {{URL|http://www.kepler.edu/}} }}
'''Kepler College''' (formerly '''Kepler College of Astrological Arts and Sciences''') is an online certificate program for the pseudoscientific study of [[astrology]].<ref name=Strauss>{{citation|date=14 Jan 2011|title=The Astrology College Story|first=Valerie|last=Strauss|newspaper=The Washington Post|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/answer-sheet/the-astrology-college-story.html}}</ref><ref name=KeplerAbout>{{cite web|title=Kepler College: About Us|url=http://www.kepler.edu/home/index.php/about|website=Kepler.edu|accessdate=26 June 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407002208/http://kepler.edu/home/index.php/about|archivedate=7 April 2016|df=}}</ref> Based out of [[Seattle, Washington]], U.S., it is named after the mathematician and astronomer [[Johannes Kepler]] (1571–1630).<ref name=Strauss/>
Kepler College was founded in 2000 as an [[Unaccredited institutions of higher learning|unaccredited institution of higher learning]]<ref name=Kuzyk/><ref name=Curry>{{citation|title=Falling Stars|last=Curry|first=Dan|year=2001|magazine=Chronicle of Higher Education|volume=47|issue=43|page=A8|issn=0009-5982}}</ref> that was authorized to grant degrees from 2000 until 2010<ref name=Strauss/> by the Higher Education Coordinating Board of Washington State.<ref name=Kuzyk>{{citation|title=Astrology in Seattle: Kepler College Looks to the Stars, But It Is Not Accredited|last=Kuzyk|first=Mark G|year=2001|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|volume=25|issue=6|pages=5–7|issn=0194-6730}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Stars Above!|last=Derbyshire|first=John|year=2001|work=National Review|volume=53|issue=13|page=26|issn=0028-0038}}</ref> Its programs were based in the liberal arts and it offered degrees in astrological studies with a focus on the history of astrology. Since 2010, students have been awarded certificates of completion of a course of study instead of degrees.<ref name=Strauss/><ref name=KeplerAbout/>
==History== In March 2000, Kepler College received provisional authorization from Washington State's Higher Education Coordinating (HEC) Board to grant degrees while the school pursued [[higher education accreditation|regional or national accreditation]], a requirement for maintaining degree-granting status.<ref name=Strauss/><ref name=Kuzyk/>
The HEC Board's decision was criticized by many academics due to Kepler's focus on the pseudoscience of astrology.<ref name=seattlepi/><ref name=Bird>{{citation|title=Pathway to the Stars|last=Bird|first=Maryann|year=2001|work=Time Europe|volume=157|issue=24|page=67}}</ref><ref name=Kuzyk/> An administrator at the University of Washington called the HEC Board's approval "ludicrous" and compared the study of astrology to "quack medicine".<ref name=seattlepi/> [[John Silber]], chancellor of [[Boston University]], wrote in a ''Boston Herald'' editorial that the school's promoters "honored Kepler not for his strength but for his weakness, as if a society advocating drunkenness named a school for [[Ernest Hemingway]]".<ref name=seattlepi>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/32348_astrology23.shtml|work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|first1=Robert|last1=McClure|title=Astrology school sets off controversy|date=22 July 2001}}</ref><ref name=Silber/> Silber also said, "The fact is that astrology, whether judged by its theory or its practice, is bunkum. In a free society there is no reason to prevent those who wish to learn nonsense from finding teachers who want to make money peddling nonsense. But it is inexcusable for the government to certify teachers of nonsense as competent or to authorize—that is, endorse—the granting of degrees in nonsense."<ref name=Silber>{{cite news|last=Silber|first=John|title=Silliness under Seattle Stars|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/73063951.html?dids=73063951:73063951&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=May+16%2C+2001&author=John+Silber&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=OP-ED%3B+Silliness+under+Seattle+stars&pqatl=google|accessdate=2 November 2012|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=16 May 2001|page=31}}</ref>
Kepler College promoted itself as the only institution in the [[Western Hemisphere]] to offer bachelor's and master's degrees in astrological studies and 31 students enrolled for the first term in July 2000.<ref name=Kuzyk/> The majority of coursework was offered online, allowing students from across the U.S. to enroll with the requirement that they were present in-person for one week of the 11-week term.<ref name=Silber/>
Kepler College did not obtain the required accreditation status by 2010 and as a result, the HEC Board revoked Kepler's right to grant degrees. After losing this authority, Kepler became an online certificate program.<ref name=Strauss/>

==Further reading== *{{citation|first=Dru|last=Sefton|title=Studies debunking astrology do little to deter followers|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/uniontrib/20060521/news_lz1c21sign.html|newspaper=Union-Tribune San Diego|date=21 May 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816030955/http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/uniontrib/20060521/news_lz1c21sign.html|archivedate=16 August 2016|df=}}—Discusses Kepler College and the science/lack of science behind astrology *{{citation|title=Astrology|author=Skeptic's Dictionary|website=skepdic.com|date=20 October 2015|url=http://skepdic.com/astrology.html}}—Discusses Kepler College and astrology from a skeptical perspective

{{Infobox UNESCO World Heritage Site | image = Confuciusmansionqufu.jpg | image_upright = 1.2 | caption = Courtyard in the Kong family mansion | location = [[Qufu]], [[Shandong]], [[China]] | part_of = [[Temple and Cemetery of Confucius and the Kong Family Mansion in Qufu]] | criteria = {{UNESCO WHS type|(i), (iv), (vi)}}(i), (iv), (vi) | ID = 704 | coordinates = {{coord|35|36|42|N|116|58|30|E|region:CN_type:landmark|display=title, inline|format=dms}} | year = 1994 | embedded = {{Infobox Chinese |child=yes |pic=Kong Family Mansion (Chinese characters).svg |piccap="Kong Family Mansion" in Chinese characters |picupright=0.4 |c=孔府 |p=Kǒng fǔ |mi={{IPAc-cmn|k|ong|3|-|f|u|3}} |j=Hung2 Fu2 |y=Húng Fú |ci={{IPAc-yue|h|ung|2|-|f|u|2}} |tl=Khóng Hú |order=st }} | locmapin = China Shandong#China | map_caption = }} The '''Kong Family Mansion''' ({{zh|c=孔府|p=Kǒng fǔ}}) was the historical residence of the [[Duke Yansheng|direct descendants of Confucius]] in the City of [[Qufu]], the hometown of [[Confucius]] in Shandong Province, China.<ref name=whatlas2005>[https://books.google.com/books?id=tFRgajxu3wIC&pg=PT86 Atlas of World Heritage: China, Long River Press, 2005]</ref> The extant structures mainly date from the [[Ming Dynasty|Ming]] and [[Qing Dynasty|Qing]] dynasties. From the mansion, the family tended to the Confucian sites in Qufu and also governed the largest private rural estate in China. The Kong family was in charge of conducting elaborate religious ceremonies on occasions such as plantings, harvests, honoring the dead, and birthdays. Today, the mansion is a museum and part of the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] "Temple and Cemetery of Confucius and the Kong Family Mansion in Qufu".
==Layout== The mansion is located immediately to the east of the [[Temple of Confucius, Qufu|Temple of Confucius]]<ref name=whatlas2005/> to which it had been formerly connected. The layout of the mansion is traditionally Chinese and separates official spaces in the style of a [[Yamen]]<ref name=fu2002>[https://books.google.com/books?id=2T1mScdj8CYC Xinian Fu, Nancy Shatzman Steinhardt: Chinese Architecture, Yale University Press, 2002]</ref> in the front of the complex from the residential quarters in the rear. Besides the yamen and the inner quarters, the complex also contains an eastern and a western study as well as a back garden.<ref name=fu2002/> Within this overall arrangement, the spatial distribution of the buildings according to the seniority, gender, and status of their inhabitants reflects the Confucian principle of order and hierarchy: The most senior descendant of Confucius took up residence in the central of the three main buildings; his younger brother occupied the Yi Gun hall to the east. The eastern study was used by the Duke of Yansheng to meet official guests and worship his ancestors.<ref name=fu2002/> The western study was used by the family for study, meals, and entertaining friends.<ref name=fu2002/> In its present layout, the mansion comprises 152 buildings with 480 rooms, which cover an area of {{convert|12470|m2|sigfig=4}}. Its tallest structure is the 4-story refuge tower ({{zh|c={{linktext|避|难|楼}}|p={{linktext|Bì|nán| Lóu}}}}) that was designed as a shelter during an attack but was never used. The mansion houses an archive with about 60,000 documents related to the life in the mansion over a period of 400 years during the Ming and Qing dynasties.<ref name=whatlas2005/>
==History== [[File:Kong mansion watchtower 2005 04 21.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Refuge tower of the mansion.]] The first mansion for the Kong family of the [[Duke Yansheng]] was built in 1038 during the [[Song Dynasty]]. In 1377, the mansion was relocated and rebuilt under orders of the [[Hongwu Emperor|first emperor of the Ming Dynasty]]. In 1503, during the reign of the [[Hongzhi Emperor]], the complex was expanded into three rows of buildings with 560 rooms and - like the neighboring Confucius Temple - nine courtyards. During the Qing Dynasty, the mansion underwent a complete renovation in 1838 only to be damaged in a fire 48 years later that destroyed the women's quarters in 1886.<ref name=fu2002/> Even during the fire, men did not dare to enter the women's part of the mansion to fight the fire, leading to greater damage to this portion of the mansion complex.<ref name=fu2002/> The damaged portions of the mansion were rebuilt two years later; the cost of both these 19th-century renovations was covered by the emperor. Despite these later renovations, the Kong Family Mansion remains the best preserved Ming-era residential complex of its size.<ref name=fu2002/> The last head of the Kong family to live in the mansion was [[Kung Te-cheng|Kong Decheng]], the 77th generation descendant of Confucius. Kong Decheng fled to [[Chongqing]] because of the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] in 1937. He did not return to Qufu but moved on to [[Taiwan]] during the [[Chinese Civil War]].<ref name=orientalarchitecture>[http://www.orientalarchitecture.com/china/qufu/kongmansion.php Kong Mansion, Qufu, China. Asian Historical Architecture]</ref>
There is another Kong Family Mansion in [[Quzhou]] built by the southern branch of Confucius descendants.
==Structures== The major structures along the central axis of the mansion (from south to north) are:
===Administrative portion===
====Main Gate==== The main entrance gate to the complex ({{zh|c={{linktext|孔|府|大|门}}|p={{linktext|Kǒng|fǔ |Dà|mén}}}}) is marked by a tablet that reads "Holy Mansion" ({{zh|c={{linktext|聖|府}}|p={{linktext|Shèng|fǔ}}}}).
====Central Courtyard==== The central courtyard is flanked to the east and west by former administrative office buildings. The administration of the Kong family's official functions and businesses was structured into departments similar to the [[Three Departments and Six Ministries|six ministries of the imperial government]]: Department of Rites (ancestor worship), Department of Seals (jurisdiction and edicts), Music, Letters, and Archives, Rent Collection and Sacrificial Fields.<ref name=leffman2003>[https://books.google.com/books?id=dA_QbQiZkB4C David Leffman, Simon Lewis, Jeremy Atiyah: China, Rough Guides, May 1, 2003]</ref>
====Gate of Double Glory==== [[File:Confucius mansion chongguang gate.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Gate of Double Glory]] Located to the north of the Central Courtyard, the Gate of Double Glory ({{zh|c={{linktext|重|光|门}}|p={{linktext|Chóng|guāng |Mén}}}}) was erected in 1503 and opened only for ceremonial purposes, visits by the emperor, or the arrival of imperial edicts.<ref name=leffman2003/><ref name=frommershortcuts>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Yva-sYW8dcEC Eastern Central China, including Qingdao and Nanjing: Frommer's ShortCuts, John Wiley & Sons, Apr 2, 2012]</ref> The structure is 6.24 meters wide, 2.03 meters deep, and 5.95 meters in height. It is also known as the "Yi Gate" ({{zh|c={{linktext|仪|门}}|p={{linktext|Yí |Mén}}}}) or "Sai Gate" ({{zh|c={{linktext|塞|门}}|p={{linktext|Sāi |Mén}}}}) .
====Great Hall==== The Great Hall ({{zh|c={{linktext|大|堂}}|p={{linktext|Dà |Táng}}}}) was the site of the duke's official business and the place for the proclamation of imperial edicts.<ref name=leffman2003/> When holding court, the duke was seated in the hall on a wooden chair that was covered by a tiger skin.<ref name=leffman2003/>
====Second Hall==== The Second Hall ({{zh|c={{linktext|二|堂}}|p={{linktext|èr |Táng}}}}) was used for receiving high-ranking officials as well as for examinations in music and rites by the duke. It contains seven tablets inscribed by emperors, including one with the character "shou" (longevity) written by the [[Empress Dowager Cixi]].<ref name=frommershortcuts/>
====Third Hall==== The Third Hall ({{zh|c={{linktext|三|堂}}|p={{linktext|Sān|Táng}}}}), also known as the "Hall of Withdrawal", was used by the duke for drinking tea.<ref name=leffman2003/>
===Residential portion===
====Gate to the Inner Apartments==== [[File:Kong mansion water outlet 2005 04 21.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Drinking water outlet at the gate to the inner apartments]] This gate ({{zh|c={{linktext|内|宅|门}}|p={{linktext|Nèi|zhái |Mén}}}}) dates to the Ming Dynasty. The gate building stands 11.8 meters wide, 6.1 meters deep, and 6.5 meters tall. During the residence of the Kong family, the gate was heavily guarded and restricted access to the residential portion of the mansion accessible only to the family and a small number of mostly female servants. Trespassing into the inner compound was punishable by death. Drinking water had to be delivered through a trough in the wall.<ref name=frommershortcuts/> On the internal ghost wall behind this entrance is a painting of a "tan" (tān), a mythical animal representing greed.<ref name=leffman2003/> Although the tan already has the [[Eight Treasures]] (associated with the [[Eight Immortals]], it is still attempting to swallow the sun. The painting was placed at the exit from the inner apartments to the administrative portion to warn the members of the Kong family against greed in their business dealings outside.
====Front Reception Hall==== The Front Reception Hall ({{zh|c={{linktext|前|上|房}}|p={{linktext|Qián|shàng |Fáng}}}}) is a structure with seven bays that was used for receiving relatives, banquets, marriage and funeral ceremonies.<ref name=leffman2003/>
====Front Main Building==== Built during the Qing era reconstruction after the fire of 1886, the Front Main Building ({{zh|c={{linktext|前|堂|楼}}|p={{linktext|Qián|táng |Lóu}}}}) has two storeys and contained the private rooms of the wife and the concubines of the duke<ref name=leffman2003/>
====Rear Building==== The rear building ({{zh|c={{linktext|后|堂|楼}}|p={{linktext|Hòu|táng |Lóu}}}}) was erected during the reign of the Qing dynasty's [[Jiaqing Emperor]]. It has a floor space of 3900 square meters and contained the private rooms of the duke.<ref name=leffman2003/> The last duke to inhabit the Rear Building was [[Kung Te-cheng|Kong Decheng]].
====Rear Five Rooms==== Originally a study for the duke, the rear five rooms ({{zh|c={{linktext|后|五|间}}|p={{linktext|Hòu|Wǔ| Jiān}}}}) become a quarter for the maids of the residence during the late Qing dynasty.
====Garden==== The Back Garden ({{zh|c={{linktext|后|花|园}}|p={{linktext|Hòu |Huā|yuán}}}}) also known as the Tieshan Garden ({{zh|c={{linktext|铁|山|园}}|p={{linktext|Tiě|shān| Yuán}}}}) was added during the Ming-era expansion of the mansion in 1503. The major building at the northern end of the garden is the Flower Hall ({{zh|c={{linktext|花|厅}}|p={{linktext|Huā |Tīng}}}}).
==See also== *[[Temple of Confucius, Qufu]] *[[Cemetery of Confucius]] *[[Mencius]]'s sites- Meng family mansion [[w:zh:孟府|孟府]], Temple of Mencius [[w:zh:孟廟|孟廟]], and Cemetery of Mencius [[w:zh:孟林|孟林]]. *[[Temple of Yan Hui]] *Temple of [[Zengzi]] [[w:zh:曾廟|曾廟]] *[[Zeng Guofan's Former Residence]]

page.title: List of Catholic dioceses in Indian Ocean Episcopal Conference

revision.text:
The [[Roman Catholic Church]] in the lesser East African Indian Ocean states (not Madagascar) is composed of only a Latin hierarchy, without a proper [[ecclesiastical province]] but joined in a single [[episcopal conference]],
comprising four exempt jurisdictions, i.e. directly dependent on the Holy See : * three exempt dioceses (on [[Mauritius]], [[Réunion]] and the [[Seychelles]]) * two missionary pre-diocesan [[Apostolic vicariate]]s (entitled to [[titular bishop]]s) : one for the [[Comoros]] and [[Mayotte]]; the other in above Mauritius. There are no titular sees. All defunct jurisdictions have current successors. There are also three papal diplomatic representations (in fact all vested in the [[apostolic nunciature]] (embassy) on Madagascar) : * an apostolic nunciature to Mauritius * an apostolic nunciature to the Seychelles * an [[apostolic delegation]] (papal legation) to the Comoros;
none to Mayotte or Reunion, as those depend on metropolitan [[France]] without full statehood. == Current jurisdictions == === Episcopal Conference of the Indian Ocean (minor African East Coast Island states) === :''all Immediately subject to the Holy See * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Port-Louis|Diocese of Port-Louis]] on [[Mauritius]] (also covers the [[British Indian Ocean Territory]]) ** [[Apostolic Vicariate of Rodrigues]], covering part of Mauritius * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Saint-Denis-de-La Réunion|Diocese of Saint-Denis-de-La Réunion]] on and for [[La Réunion]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Port Victoria o Seychelles|Diocese of Port Victoria]] on and for the [[Seychelles]] * [[Apostolic Vicariate of Archipel des Comores]], on the [[Comoros]], also for [[Mayotte]]. == Sources and external links == * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/country/KM.htm GCatholic.org Comoros]. * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/country/MU.htm GCatholic.org Mauritius]. * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/country/YT.htm GCatholic.org Mayotte]. * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/country/RE.htm GCatholic.org Réunion]. * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/country/SC.htm GCatholic.org Seychelles]. * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/country/re.html Catholic-Hierarchy entry]. {{DEFAULTSORT:List of Roman Catholic dioceses in Indian Ocean}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Réunion|*]] [[Category:Lists of Roman Catholic dioceses by country|Indian Ocean]]

page.title: List of minor Old Testament figures, A–K

revision.text:
{{see also|List of minor Old Testament figures, L–Z}} This list contains [[List of biblical names|persons named in the Bible]] of minor notability, about whom either nothing or very little is known, aside from any family connections. {{inc-lit}}
{{Compact ToC|side=yes|l=[[List of minor biblical figures, L–Z| L–Z (next page)]]|m=|n=|o=|p=|q=|r=|s=|t=|u=|v=|w=|x=|y=|z=|seealso=yes|refs=yes}}
== A ==
{{Empty section|date=October 2018}}
== Aalar == '''Aalar''', in the [[King James Version]], appears in 1 Esdras 5:36, as one of those who came up from "Thermeleth and Thelersas" who could not show their genealogical records. Instead of ''Aalar'', the NRSV reads '''Immer'''.
=== Abdeel === '''Abdeel''' ([[Obadiah|Ab'dē]] [[El (god)|el]]) (Hebrew עַבְדְּאֵל "servant of God"; akin to Arabic عبد الله ''[[Abdullah (name)|Abdullah]]''<ref>Strong's Hebrew and Greek Dictionary</ref>) is mentioned in {{bibleverse-lb|Jeremiah||36:26|HE}} as the father of [[Shelemiah]], one of three men that were commanded by King [[Jehoiakim]] to seize the prophet [[Jeremiah]] and his secretary [[Baruch ben Neriah|Baruch]].<ref name="aaa">{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=194&letter=A&search=Abdeel |title=ABDEEL |publisher=JewishEncyclopedia.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-06}}</ref> The [[Septuagint]] omits the phrase "and Shelemiah son of Abdeel", probably a scribal error due to [[homoioteleuton]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Anchor Bible Dictionary|last=Fretz|first=Mark J.|publisher=Doubleday|year=1992|isbn=9780300140811|editor-last=Freedman|editor-first=David Noel|volume=1|location=New York|page=8|chapter=Abdeel (Person)}}</ref>
===Abdi=== The name '''Abdi''' (Hebrew עַבְדִּי) is probably an abbreviation of Obediah, meaning "servant of [[Tetragrammaton|YHWH]]", according to the International Standard Bible Encyclopedia.<ref>International Standard Bible Encyclopedia, "Abdi."</ref> Easton's Bible Encyclopedia, on the other hand, holds that it means "my servant". The name "Abdi" appears three times in forms of the Bible that are in use among Jews, Protestants, and Roman Catholics. There is also one additional appearance in 1 Esdras, considered canonical in Eastern Orthodox Churches. # 1 Chronicles 6:29.<ref>This verse, in the King James Version and some other Bibles, is verse 44 of chapter 6.</ref> "And on the left hand their brethren the sons of Merari: Ethan the son of Kishi, the son of Abdi, the son of Malluch."<ref name="ReferenceA">Jewish Publication Society Bible of 1917</ref> # 2 Chronicles 29:12. "Then the Levites arose, Mahath the son of Amasai, and Joel the son of Azariah, of the sons of the Kohathites; and of the sons of Merari, Kish the son of Abdi, and Azariah the son of Jehallelel; and of the Gershonites, Joah the son of Zimmah, and Eden the son of Joah."<ref name="ReferenceA"/> # Ezra 10:26. "And of the sons of Elam: Mattaniah, Zechariah, and Jehiel, and Abdi, and Jeremoth, and Elijah."<ref name="ReferenceA"/> # 1 Esdras 9:27, where the name appears in the Hellenized form ''Oabd[e]ios.''<ref>Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' entry for "Abdi."</ref> "Of the sons of Elam: Matthanias and Zacharias and Iezrielos and Obadios and Ieremoth and Elias."<ref>''New English Translation of the Septuagint''</ref>
According to Cheyne and Black (1899), the two mentions in the Books of Chronicles are of a single individual, and the mentions in Ezra and 1 Esdras are of a second individual.<ref>Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,' entry for "Abdi."</ref>
===Abdon=== '''Abdon''' (Hebrew עַבְדּוֹן from עָבַד "to serve") is the name of four biblical individuals. It is a diminutive form of the name Ebed.<ref>Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' second entry titled "Abdon."</ref> # An Abdon in the book of Judges: see the article [[Abdon (Judges)]]. # The first-born of Gibeon of the tribe of Benjamin, mentioned only in passing in genealogies (1 Chronicles 8:30, 9:36). # Abdon the son of Micah. Josiah sent him, among others, to the prophetess Huldah, in order to discern the meaning of the recently rediscovered book of the law (2 Chronicles 34:20). He is referred to as Achbor in 2 Kings 22:12. # Abdon son of Sashak. He is only mentioned as a name in a genealogy (1 Chronicles 8:23).<ref>This section on Abdon incorporates information from the 1897 Easton's Bible Dictionary.</ref>
In addition to its use as a personal name, the proper name "Abdon" is used for a Levitical city mentioned in Joshua 21:30 and 1 Chronicles 6:74 (6:59 in some versions).<ref>Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' first entry for "Abdon."</ref>
===Abiasaph=== '''Abiasaph''' (Hebrew אֲבִיאָסָף "my father has gathered") was a son of [[Korah]] of the house of [[Levi]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Exodus#Chapter 6|Exodus 6:24]], born in Egypt. Ebiasaph is a spelling variation of Abiasaph.
===Abida=== '''Abida''' or '''Abidah''' appears twice in the Bible,<ref name="Genesis 25:4, 1 Chronicles 1:33">Genesis 25:4, 1 Chronicles 1:33</ref> as a son of [[Midian]]. Nothing further is said about him in the Bible.<ref name="cb abida">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Abida|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Abijah=== [[Abijah]] (Hebrew אֲבִיָּה "my father is YHWH") is the name of [[Abijah|eight biblical individuals]].
===Abinadab=== '''Abinadab''' (Hebrew אֲבִינָדָב "my father apportions" or "the father [''i.e.'' god of the clan] is munificent")<ref name="Black 1899">Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' entry for "Abinadab"</ref> refers to four biblical characters. Where the Hebrew text reads ''Avinadav'', Greek manuscripts of the Septuagint read ''Am(e)inadab'' or ''Abin''.<ref name="Black 1899"/> but [[Lancelot Charles Lee Brenton|Brenton]]'s translation of the Septuagint reads "Abinadab". # A man of [[Kirjath-jearim]], in whose house on a hill the [[Ark of the Covenant|ark of the covenant]] was deposited after having been brought back from the land of the [[Philistines]].<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Samuel|7:1|HE}}</ref> "It is most likely that this Abinadab was a [[Levite]]".<ref>[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/ellicott/1_samuel/7.htm Ellicott's Commentary for Modern Readers on 1 Samuel 7], accessed 26 April 2017</ref> The ark remained in his care for twenty years, guarded by his son [[Eleazar (son of Abinadab)|Eleazar]] (not to be confused with [[Eleazar]], the son of Aaron), until it was at length removed by [[David]].<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Samuel|7:1,2|HE}}; {{bibleverse|1|Chronicles|13:7|HE}}; {{bibleverse|2|Samuel|6:3|HE}}</ref> # The second of the eight sons of [[Jesse]].<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Samuel|16:8|HE}}</ref> He was with [[Saul the King|Saul]] in the campaign against the [[Philistines]] in which [[Goliath]] was slain.<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Samuel|17:13|HE}}</ref> # One of [[Saul the King|Saul]]'s sons, who perished with his father in the battle of [[Gilboa (ridge)|Gilboa]].<ref>{{bibleverse|1|Samuel|31:2|HE}}; {{bibleverse|1|Chronicles|10:2|HE}}</ref>
===Abiel=== '''Abiel''' (Hebrew אֲבִיאֵל "my father is God") was the name of two individuals mentioned in the Bible: * Son of [[Zeror]], of the [[tribe of Benjamin]], he was the grandfather of King [[Saul]] and of his commander [[Abner]]. [[:s:Bible (King James)/1 Samuel#Chapter 9|1 Samuel 9]] * An Arbathite, one of [[King David's Warriors]] who was known for his bravery. {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|11:32|HE}}
===Abimael=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|10:28|NIV}}, '''Abimael''' is the ninth of the 13 sons of [[Joktan]], a descendant of [[Shem]]. He is also mentioned in {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|1:22|NIV}}. Abimael means "God is a father."<ref>Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' entry for "Abimael."</ref>
===Abitub=== The name '''Abitub''' or '''Abitob''' appears only once in the [[Hebrew Bible]], in 1 Chronicles 8:11, where it is used for a character said to be the son of Shaharaim, in a section on the descendants of [[Benjamin]].<ref>See the entry for "Abitub" in Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia'' Biblica.</ref>
===Abiud=== The son of [[Zorobabel]] and father of [[#Eliakim, son of Abiud|Eliakim]].<ref>[[Matthew 1:13]] "Zorobabel begat Abiud; Abiud begat Eliakim"</ref>
===Adah=== {{Hebrew Name|עָדָה|ʿAda|ʿĀḏāh|}}; ''adornment''<ref>''International Standard Bible Encyclopedia'' (1915), "[http://www.biblestudytools.com/encyclopedias/isbe/adah.html Adah]."</ref> # the first wife of [[Lamech (descendant of Cain)|Lamech]], and the mother of [[Jabal (Bible)|Jabal]] and [[Jubal (Bible)|Jubal]]. ({{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|4:19–23|HE}}) # the first wife of [[Esau]], the daughter of Elon the Hittite. It has been suggested by biblical scholars that she is the same person as "Bashemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite" mentioned as a wife of Esau in Genesis 26.<ref>Easton's Bible Dictionary entry on ''Adah''</ref><ref>Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' entry on "[[s:Encyclopaedia Biblica/Acts of the apostles-Adonizedek#ADAH|Adah]]"</ref> She bore Esau's firstborn [[Eliphaz]], and became the matriarch of the [[Edomites]]. ({{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|26:34, 36:2–4|HE}})
The [[Order of the Eastern Star]] considers Adah also to be the name of the daughter of [[Jephthah]], although the Bible does not name her.
===Adalia=== Mentioned only in {{bibleverse-lb||Esther|9:8}}, '''Adalia''' is the fifth of the [[Persia]]n noble [[Haman (Bible)|Haman]]'s ten sons.<ref name="encbibadalia">Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'', entry for "Adaliah." [https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft]</ref> Adalia was slain along with his nine siblings in [[Susa]]. In various manuscripts of the Septuagint, his name is given as ''Barsa,'' ''Barel,'' or ''Barea.''<ref name="encbibadalia" />
===Adbeel=== '''Adbeel''' (Hebrew אַדְבְּאֵל "disciplined by God") '''Nadbeel''' or '''Idiba’ilu''', was the third son of [[Ishmael]] out of twelve. ({{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|25:13|HE}}) The name ''Adbeel'' is associated with the personal name and northwest tribe in [[Arabia]] known as ''Idiba’ilu'', whom [[Tiglath-Pileser III|Tiglath-Pileser]] conquered in the 8th century BCE. (Kenneth A. Mathews, 2005, p. 361){{Clarify|date=January 2017}}
===Addi=== He is the son of [[#Cosam|Cosam]] and the father of [[List of minor Old Testament figures, L–Z#Melki, son of Addi|Melki]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=luke%203&version=NIV |title=Luke 3:28 |quote=Melki, the son of Addi, the son of Cosam}}</ref>
===Adina=== In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|11:42|HE}}, Adina (lit. Slender) is listed as one of the "mighty men" of [[David]]'s army. Adina was the son of a chief of the [[Tribe of Reuben|Reubenites]] named Shiza.
===Adlai=== '''Adlai''' is in Hebrew עַדְלָי, meaning "refuge". In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|27:29|HE}}, he is the father of Shaphat, and the grandfather of the prophet Elisha. He is mentioned only in this verse.
===Admatha=== Mentioned only in {{bibleverse-lb||Esther|1:14|NIV}}, '''Admatha''' is an advisor to [[Ahasuerus]] of [[Persia]].<ref name="cbadmatha">Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'', entry for "Admatha.</ref> According to one theory, the verse has suffered from scribal error, and as it originally stood Admatha was instead Hamdatha, not an adviser to Ahaseurus but the father of [[Haman]].<ref name="cbadmatha" />
===Admin=== In some translations of Luke 3:33, '''Admin''' is an ancestor of Jesus, the father of Aminadab and son of Arni.<ref>''New Living Translation,'' ''English Standard Version,'' ''New American Standard Bible,'' ''New English Translation.''</ref>
===Adna=== '''Adna''' is the name of two biblical characters.<ref name="cbadna">[https://archive.org/stream/Encyclopaedia_Biblica_Vol_I_to_IV/EncyclodaediaBiblica_Vol_I#page/n61/mode/1up Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' entry for "Adna"]</ref> The first is one of the men in the [[Book of Ezra]] who took foreign wives.<ref name="Ezra 10:30">Ezra 10:30</ref> The second is a priest, named as the head of the priestly family Harim in the time of Joiakim.<ref>Nehemiah 12:15</ref>
===Adnah=== '''Adnah''' is the name of at least two individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cbadnah">Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'', entries for "Adnah." [https://archive.org/stream/Encyclopaedia_Biblica_Vol_I_to_IV/EncyclodaediaBiblica_Vol_I#page/n61/mode/1up]</ref> # Adnah, called ''Ednaas'' or ''Ednas'' in [[Septuagint]] manuscripts, is credited with being a commander of 300,000 soldiers in the army of [[Jehoshaphat]].<ref name="cbadnah" /> He is found in 2 Chronicles 17:14. His name is spelled with a final [[He (letter)|He]].<ref name="cbadnah" /> # Adnah, called ''Edna'' in the Septuagint, refers to a member of the [[Tribe of Manasseh]] who deserted [[Saul]] to support [[David]].<ref name="cbadnah" /> His name is spelled with either a final [[He (letter)|He]] or else a [[Heth]], depending on the manuscript.<ref name="cbadnah" />
===Aduel=== '''Aduel''', according to the [[Book of Tobit]] 1:1, was the great-grandfather of Tobit. The Book of Tobit is included in some Christian Bibles, but it is not included in Bibles historically used by Jews and most Protestants. Cheyne and Black claim that "Aduel" is "no doubt another form of Adiel."<ref name="cb aduel">[https://archive.org/stream/Encyclopaedia_Biblica_Vol_I_to_IV/EncyclodaediaBiblica_Vol_I#page/n64/mode/1up Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'', entry for "Aduel."]</ref>
===Aedias=== '''Aedias''', a descendant of Ela, appears in [[1 Esdras]] 9:27 as one of the men found to have married foreign women. 1 Esdras appears in some Christian Bibles, but not in the Bibles used by Jews and most Protestants. In the parallel verse in the [[Book of Ezra]], 10:26, the name "Elijah" is found.<ref name="cb aedias">Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' entry for "Aedias." [https://archive.org/stream/Encyclopaedia_Biblica_Vol_I_to_IV/EncyclodaediaBiblica_Vol_I#page/n64/mode/1up]</ref>
===Agee=== '''Agee''' was the father of [[Shammah]], who was one of [[King David|David]]'s mighty men ([http://bible.cc/2_samuel/23-11.htm II Samuel 23:11]). Based on interpretations of [http://bible.cc/1_chronicles/11-34.htm I Chronicles 11:34] and [http://bible.cc/2_samuel/23-34.htm II Samuel 23:32–33] Agee was either the grandfather of [[Jonathan (1 Samuel)|Jonathan]] or his brother. According to Cheyne and Black, his name is a scribal mistake, and should read "Ela"; he is the same as the Ela mentioned in 1 Kings 4:18.<ref name="cb agee">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Shutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Agee|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Aggaba=== ''For the Aggaba of 1 Esdras 5:29, see [[Hagabah]].''
===Ahab=== '''Ahab''' (Hebrew: אָחאַב, which means "brother/father") is the name of at least two biblical figures: * [[Ahab]], seventh king of Israel * Ahab, son of Koliah, who, according to Jeremiah 29:21, was labeled a false prophet by YHVH <ref>The New Jerome Biblical Commentary, 1991, pages 287288</ref>
===Aharhel=== In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|4:8|NIV}}, '''Aharhel''' (Hebrew אֲחַרְחֵל "behind the rampart") is the son of Harum of the tribe of Judah.
=== Ahasai === ''See [[Ahzai]].''
===Ahasbai=== '''Ahasbai''', the son of the Maachathite, was the father of [[Eliphelet]], one of [[King David's Warriors]] ([[:s:Bible (King James)/2 Samuel#Chapter 23|2 Samuel 23:34]]).
===Ahi=== (Hebrew אֲחִי "brother/kindred of YHWH") * Ahi is the son of [[Abdiel]] in 1 Chronicles 5:15 * Ahi is the son of Shomer in 1 Chronicles 7:34
=== Ahian === '''Ahian''' is the name given to a descendant of Manasseh in the tribal genealogies of 1 Chronicles.<ref>1 Chronicles 7:19.</ref> The name appears only in a single time in the Bible.<ref name="cb ahian">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ahian|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn=}}</ref>
===Ahiezer=== '''Ahiezer''' the son of [[Ammishaddai]] was the leader of the [[tribe of Dan]] and one of the [[leaders of the tribes of Israel]] mentioned in several places in the [[Book of Numbers]].
===Ahilud=== '''Ahilud''' is the father of [[Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud|Jehoshaphat]], who serves as [[court recorder]] to [[David]] ({{bibleverse-lb|2|Samuel|8:16|NIV}}) and [[Solomon]] ({{bibleverse-lb|1|Kings|4:3|NIV}}). In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Kings|4:12|NIV}}, Ahilud is the father of [[Baana]], an official in Solomon's court sent to gather provisions in [[Taanach]] and [[Tel Megiddo|Megiddo]], and [[Beth Shan]].
=== Ahimoth === '''Ahimoth''' appears in 1 Chronicles 6:25 (verse 10 in some Bibles). It is the name given for one of the descendants of [[Kehath]] the son of [[Levi]].
===Ahinadab=== '''[[Ahinadab]]''' (Hebrew: אחינדב ''Ahinadav'' "my brother Is noble" or "my brother has devoted himself"),<ref name="BrandEngland2003">{{cite book|author1=Chad Brand|author2=Archie England|author3=Charles W. Draper|title=Holman Illustrated Bible Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OxG5AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT101|date=1 October 2003|publisher=B&H Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4336-6978-1|page=101}}</ref> son of Iddo, is one of the twelve commissariat officers appointed by [[Solomon]] to districts of his kingdom to raise supplies by monthly rotation for his household. He was appointed to the district of [[Mahanaim]] (1 Kings 4:14), east of Jordan.
===Ahiram=== '''Ahiram''' was a son of [[Benjamin]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:38]].
===Ahisamach=== '''Ahisamach''' or Ahisamakh, also Ahis'amach ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: אחיסמך "brother of support"), of the [[tribe of Dan]], was the father of [[Aholiab]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Exodus#Chapter 31|Exodus 31:6]], [[:s:Bible (King James)/Exodus#Chapter 35|Exodus 35:34]], and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Exodus#Chapter 38|Exodus 38:23]].
=== Ahishahar === '''Ahishahar''' is the name given to a third-generation descendant of [[Benjamin]] (the eponymous forefather of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]]) in 1 Chronicles 7:10. This figure is mentioned nowhere else in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb ahishahar">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ahishahar|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref>
===Ahishar=== '''Ahishar''' (אחישר in Hebrew; meaning Brother of song, or singer), the officer who was "over the household" of Solomon ({{bibleverse-lb|1|Kings|4:6}}).
===Ahitub=== '''Ahitub''' is the name of several minor biblical figures: # '''Ahitub''', son of [[Hophni and Phinehas|Phinehas]], grandson of [[Eli (Judges)|Eli]], and brother of [[Ichabod]]. ({{bibleverse|1|Samuel|14:3,22:9–20|HE}}, {{bibleverse|1|Chronicles|9:11|HE}}) # '''Ahitub''', son of [[Amariah]] and father of [[Zadok (High Priest)|Zadok]]. ({{bibleverse|2|Samuel|8:15–17|HE}}) # '''Ahitub''', a descendant through the priestly line of the first [[Zadok (High Priest)|Zadok]]. He was an ancestor of later high priests who served during the fall of [[Jerusalem]] and after the [[Babylonian captivity|exile]]. ({{bibleverse|2|Chronicles|6:11–12|HE}}) # '''Ahitub''', a [[Benjamite]]. ({{bibleverse|1|Chronicles|8:11|HE}})
=== Ahlai === '''Ahlai''' is a name given to two individuals in the [[Books of Chronicles]]. In the opinion of [[Thomas Kelly Cheyne]], the name is probably derived from "Ahiel" or a similar name.<ref name="cb ahlai">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ahlai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref> * The first is either the son or daughter of a [[Jerahmeel]]ite man named [[Sheshan (biblical figure)|Sheshan]].<ref name="cb ahlai" /> * The second is the father or mother of Zabad, who is listed as one of [[David's Mighty Warriors]] in 1 Chronicles 11:41.<ref name="cb ahlai" />
=== Ahuzzam === '''Ahuzzam''' or '''Ahuzam''' is the name of one of the sons of "Asshur, the father of Tekoa," in a genealogy describing the desceandants of the [[Tribe of Judah]].<ref>1 Chronicles 4:6</ref> He is mentioned only in 1 Chronicles 4:6.<ref name="cb ahuzam">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ahuzam|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Ahuzzath === '''Ahuzzath''' or '''Ahuzzah'''<ref>Referred to as "Ahuzzah" in the ''New English Translation,'' but as "Ahuzzath" in most other sources.</ref> is the name given to an associate of Abimelech, king of Gerar, in Genesis 26:26. According to the [[Book of Genesis]], Ahuzzath accompanied Abimelech when Abimelech went to make a treaty with [[Isaac]]. He is mentioned nowhere else in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb ahuzzath">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ahuzzath|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn=}}</ref>
=== Ahzai === '''Ahzai''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Ahasai''') is a name which appears only in Nehemiah 11:13, where it is mentioned in passing.<ref name="cb ahasai">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ahasai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> The verse refers to a priest, called "Amashsai son of Azarel son of Ahzai son of Meshillemoth son of Immer." In the parallel name in 1 Chronicles 9:12, the name "Jahzerah" replaces "Ahzai."<ref name="cb ahasai" />
===Aiah=== '''Aiah''' (איה "Falcon") was the father of [[Rizpah]], mentioned in {{bibleverse-lb|2|Samuel|3:7|NIV}}
===Ajah=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|36:24|NIV}} and {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|1:40|NIV}}, '''Ajah''' [איה] is a son of Zibeon. ''Ajah'' means ''hawk''. Alternative spelling: ''Aiah''.
===Akan=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|36:27|NIV}} '''Akan''' is a son of [[Ezer]] and grandson of Seir the Horite. In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|1:42|NIV}} he is called [[Jaakan]].
===Akkub=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Ezra|2:45|NIV}}, '''Akkub''' is the head of a family of [[Nethinim]]. In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|3:24|NIV}}, Akkub is a son of [[Elionenai]], descendant of [[Solomon]] living in the [[Kingdom of Judah]]. In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|9:17|NIV}}, {{bibleverse-lb||Ezra|2:42|NIV}}, and {{bibleverse-lb||Nehemiah|7:45|NIV}}, Akkub is a [[Levite]] gatekeeper at the [[Temple in Jerusalem]] after the return from the [[Babylonian captivity]].
===Alexander=== '''Alexander''' was a member of the [[Sanhedrin]] named in {{bibleverse-lb||Acts|4:6|NIV}} as part of a group before whom [[Peter the Apostle|Peter]] and [[John the Apostle|John]] were required to give an account of their healing power, following their arrest on the day of [[Pentecost]].
===Allon=== In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|4:37|NIV}}, '''Allon''' is the son of Jedaiah, of the family of the Simeonites, who expelled the Hamites from the valley of Gedor.
===Alvah=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|36:40|NIV}}, '''Alvah''' is a chief of [[Edom]] and a descendant of [[Esau]]. In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|1:51|NIV}} he is called [[Aliah]].
===Alvan=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|36:23|NIV}}, '''Alvan''' is the eldest son of [[Shobal]] and a descendant of Seir the Horite. In {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|1:40|NIV}} he is called [[Alian (biblical figure)|Alian]].
===Amasa=== In {{bibleverse|2|Chr|28:1–4|NIV}}, '''Amasa''' is the son of Hadlai, and one of the leaders of [[Ephraim]] ({{bibleverse|2|Chr|28:12|NIV}}) during the reign of the evil King [[Ahaz]].
=== Amasiah === In [http://bibletools.org/index.cfm/fuseaction/Bible.show/sVerseID/11540/eVerseID/11540 2 Chronicles 17:16], '''Amasiah''' (meaning burden of [[Jehovah]]) was the son of [[Zichri]], a captain under King [[Jehoshaphat]].
===Amaziah=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Amos|7:10|NIV}}, '''Amaziah''' is a priest of Bethel who confronts Amos and rejects his prophesying against king [[Jeroboam II]]. As a result, Amos is led to prophesy the doom of Amaziah's family, the loss of his land and his death in exile. [[Jonathan Magonet]] has described Amaziah as 'a spiritual leader who believed in his own power and could not risk hearing the word of God'.<ref>Magonet, Jonathan (1992) ''Bible Lives'' (London, SCM), 116</ref>
=== Amminadib === A person mentioned in the [[Old Testament]] in {{bibleverse-lb||Song of Solomon|6:12}}, whose [[chariot]]s were famed for their swiftness. It is rendered in the margin "my willing people," and in the Revised Version "my princely people."
=== Ammizabad === '''Ammizabad''' was the son of [[Benaiah]], who was the third and chief captain of the host under [[David]] ([http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=1%20Chronicles%2027:6 1 Chronicles 27:6]).
===Amon=== '''Amon''' (Hebrew: אמן '' 'Amon'') was a city governor in the time of Kings Jehoshaphat and Ahab<ref>I Kings 22:26</ref>
===Amos=== The 10th generation grandfather of Jesus through Joseph, according to Luke 3:25.
=== Amzi === '''Amzi''' ('am-tsee') is a masculine [[Hebrew]] name meaning "my strength" or "strong." Two individuals with this name are mentioned in the Bible: * {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|6:31|HE}} indicates Amzi as a [[Levite]] man of the family of [[#Merari|Merari]]. * A son of [[Zechariah (biblical)|Zechariah]] was named Amzi. He was an ancestor to the [[Levite]] priest Adaiah ({{bibleverse-lb||Nehemiah|11:12|HE}}), who was one of the Israelite exiles under the direction of [[Nehemiah]] when he returned to [[Jerusalem]] to rebuild the city walls.
===Anah===<!-- This section is linked from [[Anah]] --> In the Book of Genesis, there are two men and one woman named '''Anah'''. * In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|36:2,14,18,25|NIV}}, Anah is a daughter of [[Zibeon]], and her daughter [[Aholibamah]] is a wife of [[Esau]]. * In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|36:20,29|NIV}} and {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|1:38|NIV}}, Anah is a son of Seir and a brother of Zibeon chief of the [[Horites]]. * In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|36:24|NIV}} and {{bibleverse-lb|1|Chronicles|1:40–41|NIV}}, Anah is a son of Zibeon, and is famed for discovering hot springs.
=== Anaiah === '''Anaiah''', a name meaning "Yahweh has answered," appears only twice in the [[Hebrew Bible]], with both appearances in [[Book of Nehemiah|Nehemiah]].<ref name="cb anaiah">On the etymology, see {{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Anaiah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> The first appearance describes [[Ezra]], a Jewish reformer, standing up to give a speech, with thirteen other people standing beside him. Anaiah is listed as one of those standing by.<ref>Nehemiah 8:4</ref> The second appearance of the name is in a list of people who signed a [[Covenant (biblical)|covenant]] between God and the Jewish people.<ref>Nehemiah 10:22</ref>
===Anak=== '''Anak''' was the father of Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai in Numbers 13:22
===Anan=== '''Anan''' was one of the Israelites who sealed the covenant after the return from Babylon<ref>{{cite web|title=Easton's Bible Dictionary|url=http://www.studylight.org/dic/ebd/view.cgi?number=T228}}</ref> ({{Bibleverse||Nehemiah|10:26|JP}}).
=== Anani === '''Anani''' is a name which appears in a genealogy in [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]].<ref>1 Chronicles 3:24</ref> It refers to a descendant of Zerubbabel. According to the [[Masoretic Text]] Anani was born six generations after [[Zerubbabel]]. For scholars, this six-generation span after Zerubbabel is the ''terminus a quo'' for the date of Chronicles—it implies that Chronicles could not have been written earlier than about 400 BCE.<ref name="Kalimi2005">{{cite book|author=Isaac Kalimi|title=An Ancient Israelite Historian: Studies in the Chronicler, His Time, Place and Writing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kmk5CDRsbwMC&pg=PA62|date=January 2005|publisher=Uitgeverij Van Gorcum|isbn=978-90-232-4071-6|pages=61–64}}</ref> In the [[Septuagint]], Anani is listed as eleven generations removed from Zerubbabel. For scholars who believe that the [[Septuagint]] reading for Anani's genealogy is correct, this places the earliest possible date for the writing of Chronicles at about 300 BCE.<ref name="Kalimi2005" />
=== Antothijah === '''Antothijah''' or '''Anthothijah''' is a name which appears only once in the [[Hebrew Bible]], in a genealogical section listing descendants of [[Benjamin]].<ref>1 Chronicles 8:24</ref><ref name="cb antothijah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Antothijah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> It is most likely an adjective used to describe a female person from the town of [[Anathoth]].<ref name="cb antothijah" /> Manuscripts of the Greek [[Septuagint]] give the name as ''Anothaith,'' ''Anathothia,'' ''Athein,'' or ''Anathotha.''<ref name="cb antothijah" />
===Aphiah=== '''Aphiah,''' of the [[tribe of Benjamin]], was an ancestor of King [[Saul]] and of his commander Abner. According to Saul, his family was the least of the tribe of Benjamin.<ref>[[:s:Bible (King James)/1 Samuel#Chapter 9|1 Samuel 9]]</ref>
=== Appaim === '''Appaim''' is a minor figure who appears in 1 Chronicles 2:30 and 31. He appears briefly in a genealogy of [[Jerahmeel]]ites, in which he is the father Ishi, son of Appaim, son of Nadab, son of Shammai, son of Onam, son of [[Jerahmeel]]. In manuscripts of the [[Septuagint]], he is called ''Ephraim,'' ''Aphphaim,'' or ''Opheim.''<ref name="cb appaim">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Appaim|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft |volume=1, A–D|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn=}}</ref>
=== Arah === '''Arah''' is the name of two minor biblical figures. The name may mean "wayfarer."<ref name="cb arah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J.
