=== Hashub === '''Hashub''' is mentioned in passing as the father of Shemaiah, a Levite who is listed among those living in Jerusalem after the end of the [[Babylonian captivity]].<ref>1 Chronicles 9:14</ref>
=== Hashubah === '''Hashubah''' is listed as one of the children of [[Zerubabel]], the governor of [[Yehud Medinata]].<ref>1 Chronicles 3:20</ref>
=== Hasrah === '''Hasrah,''' according to 2 Chronicles 34:22, is the name of an ancestor of Shallum, the husband of the prophetess [[Huldah]]. However, where the [[Book of Chronicles]] has "Hasrah," 2 Kings 22:14 has "[[Harhas]]."<ref name="cb hasrah"/>
=== Hasupha === '''Hasupha''' ('''Hashupha''' in the [[King James Version]]) is the name of a clan or family of [[Nethinim]] (temple assistants) listed in Nehemiah 7:46 and Ezra 2:43.
=== Hathach === '''Hathach''' or '''Hatach''' is the name of one of the eunuchs of [[Ahasuerus]] in the [[Book of Esther]]. He acts as an messenger between [[Esther]] and [[Mordecai]].<ref>Esther 4:5–10</ref>
=== Hathath === Hathath is only mentioned in 1 Chronicles 4:13, in a genealogical passage where he is the son of [[Othniel]], the son of [[Kenaz]].<ref name="cb hathath">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne|editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hathath|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref>
=== Hattil === The descendants of '''Hattil''' (also called '''Agia''' or '''Hagia''') are listed in Ezra 2:57 and Nehemiah 7:59 as a group of people returning from the [[Babylonian captivity]] (see [[Ezra-Nehemiah]]). They are categorized by Ezra as being descendants of "Solomon's servants" (see [[Nethinim]]). In the Greek text of 1 Esdras 5:34, a closely related work, Hattil is referred to as ''Agia'' or ''Hagia.''<ref name="cb hattil">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hattil|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Hazaiah === '''Hazaiah''' is a figure mentioned in passing in Nehemiah 11:5 as an ancestor Maaseiah, a notable leader of the [[Tribe of Judah]] in [[Yehud Medinata]].<ref>Nehemiah 11:5</ref>
===Hazo=== '''Hazo''' was the son of [[Nahor, son of Terah|Nahor]] and [[Milcah]] ({{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|22:22|HE}}).
===Heber=== '''Heber''' or '''Chéver''' ({{Hebrew Name 2 | hebrew1=חֶבֶר | hebrew2=חָבֶר | stan1=Ḥéver | stan2=Ḥáver | tiber1=Ḥéḇer | tiber2=Ḥāḇer | means="friend", "connected"}}) is the grandson of the patriarch [[Asher]] mentioned at {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|46:17|NIV}} and in {{bibleverse-lb||Numbers|26:45|NIV}}. Heber probably should not be confused with the [[Eber]] who was [[Abraham]]'s ancestor.
===Helek=== '''Helek''' was a son of [[Gilead]] of the [[Tribe of Manasseh]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:30]] and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Joshua#Chapter 17|Joshua 17:2]].
=== Heldai === '''Heldai''' is the name of two biblical figures.<ref name="cb heldai">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Heldai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn=}}</ref> According to the ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' it should most likely be given alternate vowels as ''Holdai'' or ''Huldai.''<ref name="cb heldai" /> # Heldai son of Baanah the Netophathite is listed as one of [[David's Mighty Warriors]], and also in a list of military leaders given in 1 Chronicles 27:15. He is called "Heled" in 1 Chronicles 11:30, and "Heleb" in 2 Samuel 23:29.<ref name="cb heldai" /> # A Jew living in [[Babylonia]], mentioned in Zechariah 6:10. He is called ''Helem'' in Zechariah 6:10.<ref name="cb heldai" />
=== Helkai === '''Helkai''' is a name used in Nehemiah 12:15, in a list of priestly clan leaders in the "days of [[Joiakim (high priest)|Joiakim]]."<ref>Nehemiah 12:12–21</ref> The text refers to Helkai as leading a clan named Meraioth. According to the ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' the name is an abbreviated form of "Hilkiah."<ref name="cb helkai">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Helkai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Helon=== '''Helon''' was a member of the house of [[Zebulun]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 1|Numbers 1:9]]. He was the father of [[#Eliab|Eliab]].
=== Hemam === '''Hemam''' or '''Homam''' is the name of the son of Lotan and grandson of Seir the Horite, according to Genesis 36:22 and 1 Chronicles 1:39.
=== Henadad === '''Henadad''' is a biblical name which appears only in [[Ezra-Nehemiah]]. In a passage which describes the rebuilding of the wall of Jerusalem, two "sons of Henadad", Bavai and Binnui, are named as taking responsibility for portions of the wall.<ref>Nehemiah 3:18 and 24.</ref> Binnui reappears later, where he is described as a Levite and as one of the signatories of the covenant between Ezra, God, and the people of Judah.<ref>Nehemiah 10:9</ref> The "sons of Henadad," though without any specific individuals named, are mentioned in also in Ezra 3:9, a "difficult passage".<ref name="cb henadad">{{cite book |author=Stanley Arthur Cook |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=TITLE|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Stanley Arthur Cook }}</ref>
===Hepher=== '''Hepher''' was a son of [[Manasseh (tribal patriarch)|Manasseh]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:32]] and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Joshua#Chapter 17|Joshua 17:2]]. See [[List of minor biblical places#Hepher|List of minor biblical places § Hepher]].
=== Hermogenes === A '''Hermogenes''' is briefly mentioned in 2 Timothy 1:15, where he, along with someone named Phygelus, are described as having "turned away" from [[Paul the Apostle]]. Nothing more is known about Hermogenes.<ref name="cb hermogenes">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hermogenes|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Hezekiah=== ''This section is about the minor biblical figures named Hezekiah. For the king Hezekiah, see [[Hezekiah]].''
'''Hezekiah''' is the name of three minor figures in the [[Hebrew Bible]]. In some Bibles the variant spellings '''Hizkiah''' and '''Hizkijah''' occur. * A son of Neariah and descendant of [[David]] mentioned in the royal genealogy of 1 Chronicles 3.<ref>Verse 22.</ref> * A figure mentioned in passing in Ezra 2:16 and Nehemiah 7:21, as the ancestor of some of the exiles who returned from the [[Babylonian captivity]]. * An ancestor of the prophet Zephaniah.<ref>Zephaniah 1:1</ref>
===Hezron=== '''[[Hezron]]''' or '''Hetzron''' ({{Hebrew Name|חֶצְרוֹן|Ḥetsron|Ḥeṣrôn|"Enclosed" <ref name="Smith's Bible Dictionary">Smith's Bible Dictionary</ref> }}) is the name of two men in [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]]. * In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|46:9|NIV}}, '''Hezron''' is a son of [[Reuben (Bible)|Reuben]] and the founder of the '''Hezronites'''. * In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|46:12|NIV}}, '''Hezron''' is grandson of [[Judah (biblical figure)|Judah]] and the son of [[Pharez]].
===Hiel=== '''Hiel''' the Bethelite (Heb. אֲחִיאֵל, חִיאֵל; "the [divine] brother, or kinsman, is God")<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0009_0_08927.html | title=Hiel}}</ref>) rebuilt Jericho during the reign of King Ahab. (I Kings 16:34)
=== Hillel of [[Pirathon]]=== * The father of [[Abdon (Judges)|Abdon]], in the Book of Judges (Judges 12:13-15).
=== Hiram === '''Hiram''' (Hebrew: חירם ''Ḥiram'') of Tyre, son of a widow of the tribe of Naphtali whose father was a craftsman in bronze, was given the metal work of King Soloman's temple. I Kings 7:13–14. According to The Interpreter's Bible, Hiram is a shortened form of אחירם ('''aḥîrām'', "brother of Ram [the lofty one].")<ref>The Interpreter's Bible, Buttrick, 1954, Abingdon Press, Volume III, Snaith, p. 51</ref>
=== Hobab === '''Hobab''' was [[Moses]]' brother-in-law ({{bibleverse-lb||Numbers|10:29|HE}}) the son of Moses's father-in-law, Jethro ({{bibleverse-lb||Judges|4:11|HE}}). The relevant part of Numbers 10:29 reads: "And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses' father-in-law". That of Judges 4:11 reads: "Now Heber the Kenite had severed himself from the Kenites, even from the children of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses". Moses invited Hobab to take part in the [[The Exodus|Exodus journey]] into the [[Promised Land]], wanting to make use of his local knowledge, but Hobab preferred to return home to [[Midian]] ({{bibleverse-lb||Numbers|10:29–31|HE}}).
=== Hod === '''Hod''' is a biblical name which appears only in 1 Chronicles 7:37.<ref name="cb hod">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hod|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> He appears as one character in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Asher]].
===Hodaviah=== '''Hodaviah''' is the name of three individuals in the Bible.<ref name="cb hodaviah">{{cite book |author=Stanley Arthur Cook |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hodaviah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Stanley Arthur Cook }}</ref> The [[Revised Version]] and [[King James Version]] of the Bible sometimes spell it as '''Hodaiah,''' '''Hodevah,''' or '''Hodeiah.'''<ref name="cb hodaviah" /> * Hodaviah, a clan leader in the [[Tribe of Manasseh]], according to 1 Chronicles 5:24. * Hodaviah son of Hassenuah appears as the ancestor of a [[Tribe of Benjamin|Benjamite]] man living in Jerusalem after the [[Babylonian captivity]].<ref>1 Chronicles 9:7</ref> This Hodaviah is called "Judah son of Hassenuah" in Nehemian 11:9.<ref name="cb hodaviah" /> * Hodaviah son of Elioenai is described as a descendant of [[Zerubbabel]] in 1 Chronicles 3:24
=== Hodesh === '''Hodesh''' is a figure who appears in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]] in [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]].<ref>1 Chronicles 8:9</ref> The name might mean "born at the feast of the new moon," or else it may be a misspelling of Ahishahar.<ref name="cb hodesh">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hodesh|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Hoham === '''Hoham''', according to the [[Book of Joshua]], was the king of Hebron, defeated in Joshua's conquest.<ref>Joshua 10</ref>
=== Homam === ''See [[Hemam]].''
=== Hon === See [[On (biblical figure)]]
===Hori=== '''Hori''' is the personal name of two biblical individuals, as well as being the Hebrew term for a [[Horites|Horite]]. * Hori of the house of [[Simeon (Hebrew Bible)|Simeon]] was the father of [[#Shaphat|Shaphat]], a scout sent to [[Canaan]] prior to the crossing of the [[Jordan River]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 13|Numbers 13:5]]. * Hori is recorded as the name of Lotan, the son of Seir the Horite, according to Genesis 36:22.
=== Hoshama === '''Hoshama''' is the name of one of the seven sons of [[Jeconiah]], according to 1 Chronicles 3:18, the only place in the Bible that refers to him.<ref name="cb hoshama">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hoshama|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> It is a shortened version of the name "Jehoshama."<ref name="cb hoshama" />
=== Hotham === '''Hotham''' is the name for two individuals found in the BIble.<ref name="cb hotham">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Hotham|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> A Hotham appears in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Asher]] in 1 Chronicles 7:32, but this individual is referred to as "Helem" in verse 35.<ref name="cb hotham" /> Another Hotham, though the [[King James Version|KJV]] calls him '''Hothan''', can be found in 1 Chronicles 11:44, where his sons Shama and Jeiel are listed among [[David's Mighty Warriors]]. This second Hotham is called an Aroerite.<ref name="cb hotham" />
=== Hothir === '''Hothir''' is listed as a son of David's "seer" [[Heman the Ezrahite|Heman]] in 1 Chronicles 25:4 and 28.
=== Hubbah === ''See [[Jehubbah]].''
===Huppim=== '''Huppim''' (חופים) or '''Hupham''' (חופם) was the ninth son of [[Benjamin]] in Genesis 46:21 and Numbers 26:39.
===Hushim=== '''Hushim''', according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 46|Genesis 46:23]], was the name of the sons of Dan, listed among the 70 souls to migrate to Egypt with Jacob. Numbers 26:42 calls Dan's son '''Shuham''', and his descendants the Shuhamites. The [[Talmud]] names him as the murderer of [[Esau]].<ref>Sotah 13a</ref>
=== Huzzab === '''Huzzab''' is either a name or a word which appears in Nahum 2:7 (verse 8 in some Bibles). In a passage in which Nahum is predicting the fall of Nineveh, the prophet says, "Huzzab shall be led away captive" in the [[King James Version]]. However, a number of more contemporary versions since the late nineteenth century have interpreted the word as a verb, meaning "and it has been decreed."<ref name="cb huzzab">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Huzzab|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref><ref>See also the ''New International Version'' and ''New Living Translation.''</ref>
==I== {{compact ToC|top=yes|center=yes}}
=== Ibneiah === '''Ibneiah''' is the name given in Chronicles to a leader of a clan in the [[Tribe of Benjamin]] which returned to [[Yehud Medinata]] after the [[Babylonian captivity]].<ref>1 Chronicles 9:8</ref> The same character is referred to as "Gabbai" in the parallel passage in [[Book of Nehemiah|Nehemiah]].<ref>Nehemiah 11:8</ref><ref name="cb ibneiah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ibneiah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Ibnijah === '''Ibnijah''' is a figure who is mentioned indirectly in 1 Chronicles 9:8, by way of his descendant "Meshullam, son of Shephatiah, son of Reuel, son of Ibnijah." He was a Benjamite.<ref name="cb ibnijah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ibnijah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Ibsam === According to [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]], '''Ibsam''' was the son of [[Tola (son of Issachar)|Tola]], who in turn was the son of [[Issachar]].<ref>1 Chronicles 7:2</ref> He is called '''Jibsam''' in the [[King James Version]].<ref name="cb jibsam">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jibsam|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Idbash === '''Idbash''', according to 1 Chronicles 4:3, was one of the sons of [[Etham (biblical figure)|Etham]], a figure who appears in the Chronicler's genealogy of the [[Tribe of Judah]].
===Igal=== '''Igal''' is the name of three biblical figures. * Igal son of [[#Joseph|Joseph]] of the house of [[Issachar]], a scout sent to [[Canaan]] prior to the crossing of the [[Jordan River]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 13|Numbers 13:7]]. * Igal son of Nathan of Zobah is mentioned only in 2 Samuel 23:36 in a list of [[David's Mighty Warriors]]. * Igal son of Shemaiah is listed as a descendant of Zerubbabel in 1 Chronicles 3:22. This last figure is called '''Igeal''' in the [[King James Version]], although his name in Hebrew is the same as the other two Igals.<ref name="cb igal">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Igal|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Igdaliah === '''Igdaliah''' (Hebrew ''yigdalyahu'') is mentioned in passing as the father of a man named Hanan in Jeremiah 35:3. According to the [[Book of Jeremiah]], the sons or descendants of Hanan son of Igdaliah had their own chamber in the temple at Jerusalem, which was the site of the famous object-lesson concerning Jeremiah and the [[Rechabite]]s.<ref>Jeremiah 35</ref> The ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'' claimed that the name Igdaliah was most likely a mistaken form of the name Gedaliah.<ref name="cb igdaliah">{{cite book|editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Igdaliah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Ikkesh=== '''Ikkesh''' the [[Tekoa (ancient town)|Tekoite]] was the father of Ira, one of [[King David's Warriors]] ([[:s:Bible (King James)/2 Samuel#Chapter 23|2 Samuel 23:26]], [[:s:Bible (King James)/1 Chronicles#Chapter 11|1 Chronicles 11:28]]).
=== Ilai === ''See [[Zalmon (biblical figure)]].''
===Imla=== '''Imla''' (Hebrew – ימלא, "whom God will fill up" <ref name="Smith's Bible Dictionary">Smith's Bible Dictionary</ref>), the father of Micaiah, which latter was the prophet who foretold the defeat of the allied kings of Judah and Israel against Ramoth-gilead (2 Chron 18:7–8). In the parallel passage (1 Kings 22:8–9) his name is written ''Imlah''.
===Immer=== '''Immer''' was a member of the priestly family whose sons, [[Hanani]] and Zebadiah, had both taken pagan wives but repented during the communal confession instigated by the biblical priest [[Ezra]].<ref>Ezra 10:20</ref>
=== Imna === '''Imna''' is a biblical name which appears only in 1 Chronicles 7:35, in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Asher]].<ref name="cb imna">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Imna|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Imrah === '''Imrah''' is a biblical name which appears only in 1 Chronicles 7:36, in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Asher]].<ref name="cb imrah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Imrah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Imri === '''Imri''' is the name of two individuals mentioned in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb imri">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Imri|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * An Imri is mentioned in passing in the ancestry of a man named Uthai, who according to 1 Chronicles 9:4 lived in Jerusalem after the return from the [[Babylonian captivity]]. * A man named "Zakkur son of Imri" is recorded as taking responsibility for a section of the wall in the project of rebuilding the wall of Jerusalem, according to Nehemiah 3:2.
=== Iphdeiah === '''Iphdeiah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Iphediah''') is a name which appears very briefly as that of "Iphdeiah son of Shashak," mentioned only in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Asher]] according to [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]].<ref>1 Chronicles 8:25</ref><ref name="cb iphediah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Iphediah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Ir === ''See [[Iri (biblical figure)]].''
===Ira the Jairite=== '''Ira the [[Jair]]ite''' was David's priest or chief minister after [[Sheba son of Bichri|Sheba]]'s rebellion.<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Samuel|20:26|NKJV}}</ref> He is described as David's priest by the [[English Standard Version]] and [[New International Version]], his chief ruler by the [[King James Version]] and his chief minister by the [[New King James Version]].
===Irad=== In {{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|4:18|NIV}}, '''Irad''' is the son of [[#Enoch|Enoch]], the grandson of [[Cain]] and the father of [[Mehujael]].
=== Iram === '''Iram''' is a name which appears in Genesis 36:43. In the [[Masoretic Text]] as it now stands, Iram is identified as a "tribal leader" (Hebrew ''alluph'') of [[Edom]]. However, Thomas Kelly suggests that originally the text may have identified Iram and the other "tribal leaders" as the names not of individuals, but of clans, using the Hebrew word ''eleph'' to mean "clan."<ref name="cb iram">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Iram|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Iri === '''Iri''', according to 1 Chronicles 7:7, was one of the sons of Bela, who was the son of [[Benjamin]], eponymous founder of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]]. In verse 12, he is referred to simply as '''Ir'''.<ref name="cb iri">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Iri|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Irijah=== '''Irijah''' (Hebrew יראייה ''yiriyyah'') is an official who arrests Jeremiah on suspicion of desertion.<ref>Jeremiah 37:13</ref>
=== Iru === '''Iru''' is a name mentioned only once in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb iru">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Iru|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> In 1 Chronicles 4:15, Iru is listed as one of the sons of [[Caleb]]. The other two were Elah and Naam.
===Iscah=== {{main|Iscah}} '''Iscah''' or '''Jesca''' ([[Jessica (given name)|Jessica]]) was a daughter of [[Haran]], sister of [[Lot (Bible)|Lot]] and [[Milcah]] according to Genesis 11:29.
=== Ishbah === ''For the "Ishbah father of Eshtemoa" mentioned in 1 Chronicles, see [[List of minor biblical tribes#Ishbah|List of minor biblical tribes § Ishbah]].''
=== Ishbi-benob === '''Ishbi-benob''' is a name which appears in the [[Qere and Ketiv|Qere]] of the [[Masoretic Text]] at 2 Samuel 21:16.<ref name="cb ishbi-benob">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ishbi-benob|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref> ''Qere'' is the term for the version of the text traditionally read aloud in synagogues. The [[Qere and Ketiv|Ketiv]], the version written but not read aloud, reads somewhat differently, in a manner that suggested to [[Thomas Kelly Cheyne]] that the opening words of the verse were not the name of the giant, but words that indicated that David and his soldiers stayed in (the city of) Nob.<ref name="cb ishbi-benob" /> Whatever the case with the Ketiv, the Qere as it now stands asserts that Ishbi-benob was the name of a Philistine giant, who was killed by Abishai son of Zeruiah.<ref name="cb ishbi-benob" /><ref>2 Samuel 21:16–17</ref> [[Wilhelm Gesenius|Gesenius]] interprets his name as meaning "dweller upon the height".<ref>[http://biblehub.com/commentaries/pulpit/2_samuel/21.htm Pulpit Commentary] on 2 Samuel 21, accessed 19 August 2017</ref> In [[Lancelot Charles Lee Brenton|Brenton]]'s [[Septuagint]] Translation, his name is given as Jesbi, the progeny of [[List of minor biblical figures, L–Z#Rapha|Rapha]].<ref>[http://biblehub.com/sep/2_samuel/21.htm Brenton's Septuagint Translation, 2 Samuel 21:16]</ref>
=== Ishhod === '''Ishhod''' ([[King James Version]] '''Ishod''') is a figure mentioned only once in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb ishod">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ishod|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref> 1 Chronicles 7:18 lists Ishod as a son of Hammoleketh in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Manasseh]].
=== Ishiah === ''See [[Jesiah]].''
=== Ishijah === ''See [[Jesiah]].''
=== Ishmaiah === '''Ishmaiah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Ismaiah''') is the name of two biblical figures.<ref name="cb ishmaiah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ishmaiah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * Ishmaiah son of Obadiah was the leader of the [[Tribe of Zebulun]] in the time of [[David]], according to 1 Chronicles 27:19. He is called ''Samaias'' in the [[Septuagint]].<ref name="cb ishmaiah" /> * Ishmaiah the Gibeonite, according to 1 Chronicles 12:4, was one of [[David's Mighty Warriors]].
=== Ishmerai === '''Ishmerai''' is a biblical figure mentioned only in 1 Chronicles 8:18, where he is called "the son of Elpaal" in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]].<ref name="cb ishmerai">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ishmerai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> He may be the same character as the "Shemer" or "Shemed" mentioned in 1 Chronicles 8:12.<ref name="cb ishmerai" />
=== Ishod === ''See [[Ishhod]].''
=== Ishpah === '''Ishpah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Ispah''') is a name which appears in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]].<ref>1 Chronicles 8:16</ref><ref name="cb ispah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ispah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> According to 1 Chronicles 8, Ishpah was the son of Beriah, the son of Elpaal, the son of Shaharaim.<ref>1 Chronicles 8:8–13, 16–17</ref>
=== Ishpan === '''Ishpan''' is a figure who appears only once in the [[Hebrew Bible]], in a genealogical passage describing the people of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]].<ref name="cb ishpan">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ishpan|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> 1 Chronicles 8 calls him the son of Shashak, the son of Elpaal, the son of Shaharaim.<ref>See verses 8–11, 13–14, 22.</ref>
=== Ishuah === ''See [[Ishvah]].''
=== Ishuai === ''See [[Ishvah]].''
===Ishui=== ''See [[Ishvi]].''
=== Ishvah === '''Ishvah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Ishuah''' and '''Isuah''') was one of the sons of [[Asher]] according to Genesis 46:17 and 1 Chronicles 7:30, although he is missing from the list of the sons of Asher found in Numbers 26:44.<ref name="cb ishvah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ishvah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Ishvi === '''Ishvi''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Ishui,''' '''Isui''', '''Jesui''', and '''Ishuai''') is the name of two figures in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb ishvi">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ishvi|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref> * Ishvi is the name given to a son of [[Asher]], eponymous founder of the [[Tribe of Asher]], in Genesis 46:17, Numbers 26:44, and 1 Chronicles 7:30. His descendants are called Ishvites in Numbers 24:44. Genesis 46 places him in the list of 70 persons who went down into Egypt with [[Jacob]], the father of Asher and the other eleven [[Twelve Tribes of Israel|Tribes of Israel]]. * Ishvi is the name of a son of [[Saul]] in 1 Samuel 14:49.
=== Ismaiah === ''See [[Ishmaiah]].''
=== Ispah === ''See [[Ishpah]].''
=== Isshiah === ''See [[Jesiah]].''
=== Isshijah === ''See [[Jesiah]].''
===Isui=== ''See [[Ishvi]].''
=== Ithai === ''See [[List of minor biblical figures, A–K#Ittai|Ittai]].''
=== Ithmah === '''Ithmah''' is a name which appears only once in the [[Hebrew Bible]], in 1 Chronicles 11:46, where "Ithmah the Moabite" is listed as one of [[David's Mighty Warriors]].<ref name="cb ithmah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ithmah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Ithran === '''Ithran''' is the name given for two figures in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb ithran">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ithran|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * Ithran, son of Dishon, son of Anah, son of Zibeon, son of Seir the [[Horites|Horite]].<ref>See Genesis 36:26 and in the parallel passage, 1 Chronicles 1:41</ref> This Ithran represents the name of a Horite clan.<ref name="cb ithran" /> * Ithran, son of Zophah, son of Helem appears in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Asher]].<ref>1 Chronicles 7:37</ref> The ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'' identifies the "Jether" of 1 Chronicles 7:38 as probably being identical to this Ithran.<ref name="cb ithran" />
===Ithream=== '''Ithream''' was the son of [[David]] and [[Eglah]], David's sixth son, according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/2 Samuel#Chapter 3|II Samuel 3:5]].
=== Ittai === '''Ittai''' (and in Chronicles, '''Ithai''' once) is the name given one or two biblical figures: * Ittai the [[Gath (city)|Gittite]] appears alongside 600 soldiers as a [[Philistine]] ally of David in the time leading up to [[Absalom]]'s rebellion.<ref name="cb ittai">{{cite book |author=Stanley Arthur Cook |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Ittai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Stanley Arthur Cook }}</ref> Having only recently arrived in [[Jerusalem]], David gives him an option to return home to Gath, but Ittai confirms his loyalty to David and helps him evacuate the city.<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Samuel|15:18–22|NKJV}}</ref> During the rebellion itself, he serves as commander of a third of David's army.<ref name="cb ittai" /> * Ittai "son of Ribai, from Gibeah, of the children of Benjamin" is listed as one of [[David's Mighty Warriors]].<ref>2 Samuel 23:29</ref> His association with [[Gibeah]] and the [[Tribe of Benjamin]] "probably" distinguish him from the Gittite Ittai, according to [[Stanley Arthur Cook]].<ref name="cb ittai" /> This Benjamite Ittai is once called Ithai in 1 Chronicles 11:31.<ref name="cb ittai" />
=== Izhar === ''For the Levitical clan, see [[Izhar]].''
'''Izhar''' son of Hela is a figure who appears in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Judah]], in 1 Chronicles 4:7. He is called [[Izhar]] according to the variant reading known as [[Qere and Ketiv|Qere]]. According to the [[Qere and Ketiv|Ketiv]] his name is '''Zohar'''. The [[King James Version]] calls him '''Jezoar'''.
=== Izrahiah === '''Izrahiah''' ('''Jezrahiah''') is the name of two biblical figures. * Izrahiah son of Uzzi, son of Tola, son of Issachar appears in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Issachar]].<ref>1 Chronicles 7:3</ref> * Izrahiah ([[King James Version|KJV]] Jezrahiah) is, according to Nehemiah 12:42, a leader of singers in a procession headed by [[Nehemiah]].
=== Izri === '''Izri''' ('''Zeri''') appears in a list of persons responsible for liturgical music in the time of [[David]], according to 1 Chronicles 25:11. In 1 Chronicles 25:3, he is called Zeri.<ref name="cb izri">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Izri|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Izziah === '''Izziah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Jeziah'''), a descendant of Parosh, is listed as one of the men who married foreign wives in the time of [[Nehemiah]].<ref>Ezra 10:25</ref>
==J== {{compact ToC|top=yes|center=yes}}
=== Jaanai === ''See [[Janai (biblical figure)]]. See [[Djenné|Djenne]]'.''
=== Jaareshiah === '''Jaareshiah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Jaresiah''') is a name which appears only 1 Chronicles 8:27, where Jaaresiah is identified as one of the sons of Jeroham.<ref name="cb jaresiah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=TITLE|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> The text does not identify any information about Jeroham's parentage, but the passage is part of a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]].<ref name="cb jaresiah" />
=== Jaasai === ''See [[Jaasu]].''
=== Jaasau === ''See [[Jaasu]].''
=== Jaasiel === '''Jaasiel''' ('''Jasiel''') is the name of one of [[David's Mighty Warriors]].<ref>1 Chronicles 11:47</ref> He is referred to in Hebrew as ''hammitsovayah'', which has been variously translated as "the Mezobaite," "the Mesobaite," or "from Zobah."<ref name="cb jaasiel">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jaasiel|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref><ref>"Mesobaite" in the [[King James Version]], "Mezobaite" in the [[Revised Version]] and [[New International Version]], "from Zobah" in the [[New Living Translation]].</ref> A "Jaasiel son of Abner" is listed as a Benjamite leader in 1 Chronicles 27:21, who may be the same person.<ref name="cb jaasiel" />
=== Jaasu === '''Jaasu''' (also called '''Jaasau''', '''Jaasai''') is a name which appears in a list of men alleged to have married foreign women in the time of [[Nehemiah]].<ref>Ezra 10:37</ref>
=== Jaaziah === '''Jaaziah''' is listed as one of the sons of [[Merari]] in a passage discussing the various divisions of [[Levite]]s.<ref>1 Chronicles 24:26–27</ref>
=== Jaaziel === '''Jaaziel''' is the name of a [[Levite]] musician who appears in 1 Chronicles 15:18. He reappears as "Aziel" in 15:20.<ref name="cb jaaziel">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jaaziel|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jacan === '''Jacan''' (or '''Jachan''') is a name which appears once in the [[Hebrew Bible]], in a list of [[Tribe of Gad|Gadites]] in Chronicles.<ref>1 Chronicles 5:13</ref><ref name="cb jachan">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jachan|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Jachin=== '''Jachin''' was a son of [[Simeon (Hebrew Bible)|Simeon]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 46|Genesis 46:10]], [[:s:Bible (King James)/Exodus#Chapter 6|Exodus 6:15]], and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:12]], one of the 70 souls to migrate to Egypt with Jacob.
=== Jahath === '''Jahath''' is the name of several individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jahath">{{cite book |author=Stanley Arthur Cook |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jahath|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Stanley Arthur Cook }}</ref> * Jahath son of Reaiah, son of Shobal, son of [[Judah (son of Jacob)]] is mentioned in 1 Chronicles 4:2, in a genealogical passage describing the [[Tribe of Judah]]. * Jahath is a name applied to various [[Levite]]s in 1 Chronicles 6:20 (verse 5 in some Bibles), 6:43 (verse 28 in some Bibles), 23:10, 24:22; and 2 Chronicles 34:12.<ref name="cb jahath" />
=== Jahaziah === ''See [[List of minor biblical figures, A–K#Jahzeiah|Jahzeiah]].''
===Jahleel=== '''Jahleel''' was a son of [[Zebulun]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 46|Genesis 46:14]] and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:26]]. He was one of the 70 persons to migrate to Egypt with Jacob.
=== Jahmai === ''For the Jahmai of 1 Chronicles 7:2, see [[List of minor biblical tribes#Jahmai|List of minor biblical tribes § Jahmai]].''
===Jahzeel=== '''Jahzeel''' was a son of [[Naphtali]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 46|Genesis 46:24]] and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:48]]. He was one of the 70 persons to migrate to Egypt with Jacob.
=== Jahzeiah === '''Jahzeiah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Jahaziah''') son of Tikvah is one of the figures listed in the [[Book of Ezra]] as opposing Ezra's prohibition on marriages with foreign women.<ref>Ezra 10:15</ref><ref name="cb jahaziah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jahaziah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jahzerah === '''Jahzerah''' is a name which appears only in 1 Chronicles 9:12.<ref name="cb jahzera">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jahzerah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> See [[Ahzai]].
=== Jakeh === '''Jakeh''' is a name that appears only in Proverbs 30:1, where part of the [[Book of Proverbs]] is ascribed to a man called "[[Agur|Agur son of Jakeh]]". Franz Delitzsch proposed that the name "Jakeh" means "scrupulously pious."<ref name="cb jakeh">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jakeh|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref>
=== Janai === '''Janai''' ('''Jaanai''') is a name that appears only 1 Chronicles 5:12, where Janai is listed as a descendant of Gad. According to the ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'', the name represents the name of a clan within the [[Tribe of Gad]].<ref name="cb jaanai">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jaanai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jarib === '''Jarib''' is the name of three individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]], and appears once in the [[King James Version]] of 1 Maccabees 14:29. * In 1 Chronicles 4:24, one of the sons of [[Simeon (son of Jacob)]] is called Jarib. In other passages, he is called [[Jachin (biblical figure)|Jachin]].<ref name="cb jarib">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jarib|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * A Jarib appears in a list of leaders recruited by Ezra to find Levites for the resettlement of Jerusalem.<ref>Ezra 8:16</ref> * A priest by the name of Jarib is mentioned in a list of men who married foreign women in Ezra 10:18. * In 1 Maccabees 14:29, in the King James Version a priest named Simon is described as being "of the posterity of Jarib." The ''New English Translation of the Septuagint'' transliterates the name as ''Ioarib,'' while the ''New American Bible'' reads ''Joarib.''
=== Jakim === ''This section is about individuals named Jakim. For the priestly division named Jakim, see [[List of minor biblical tribes#Jakim|the priestly division of Jakim]].''
'''Jakim''' is the name of one individual mentioned in the [[Hebrew Bible]], as well as one individual mentioned in some manuscripts of the New Testament's [[Gospel of Matthew]]. In a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]], in 1 Chronicles 24:12, a Jakim appears, as the son of Shimei (who is referred to as Shema in verse 13).<ref name="cb jakim">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jakim|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> In some Greek manuscripts of Matthew, a Jakim appears between Josiah and Jechoniah in a genealogy of Jesus.<ref>Matthew 1:11</ref><ref name="cb jakim" />
=== Jalon === '''Jalon''' was one of four sons of [[Ezrah]], and the uncle of Miriam, Shammai and Ishbah (father of Eshtemoa). ({{bibleverse-lb|1|Chr.|4:17|HE}})
===Jamin=== The name '''Jamin''' means right hand. There are three different Jamins in the Bible: # a son of [[Simeon (Hebrew Bible)|Simeon]] according to {{bibleverse||Genesis|46:10|HE}}, {{bibleverse||Exodus|6:15|HE}}, and {{bibleverse||Numbers|26:12|HE}}. He was one of the 70 souls to migrate to Egypt with Jacob. # Man of Judah, see {{bibleverse|1|Chronicles|2:27|HE}} # Post exile Levite who interpreted the law, see {{bibleverse||Nehemiah|8:7,8|HE}}
=== Jamlech === '''Jamlech''' is a figure who appears once in the [[Hebrew Bible]], in list of kin group leaders in the [[Tribe of Simeon]], who according to the Bible lived in the time of [[Hezekiah]] and exterminated the Meunim.<ref>1 Chronicles 4:34–38</ref><ref name="cb jamlech">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jamlech|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Japhia=== '''Japhia''' was the king of [[Lachish]], one of the five kings of the [[Amorites]] whose battle against the settling Israelites led by [[Joshua]] is reported in {{bibleverse||Joshua|10:1–15|KNJV}}. Along with the other four kings, he was subsequently found in a cave at Makkedah, where he was killed and buried by Joshua and his forces ({{bibleverse||Joshua|10:26–27|KNJV}}).
=== Jareb === '''Jareb''' is a name which appears in Hosea 5:13 and 10:16 in some translations of the Bible.<ref>For example, see the ''King James Version'', ''Revised Version'', and ''New American Standard Bible''.</ref> In both passages, the Hebrew text refers to a ''mlk yrb'' ([[King James Version|KJV]] "King Jareb") in a way that implies that ''mlk yrb'' is the king of Assyria.<ref name="albrightjareb">[https://www.jstor.org/stable/1457169 Albright, W. F. “The Archaeological Background of the Hebrew Prophets of the Eighth Century”. ''Journal of Bible and Religion'', vol. 8, no. 3, 1940, p. 134.]</ref> However, no Assyrian king by the name of "Jareb" is known to history, which has led to a variety of conjectures about what the phrase refers to.<ref name="cb jareb">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jareb|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref> According to W. F. Albright, the "definitive solution" to the problem is that the text should read ''mlk rb'' or ''mlky rb'', meaning "the great king", a Hebrew translation of the common Assyrian royal title ''sharru rabu''.<ref name="albrightjareb" /> The proposed emendation to "great king" has been accepted in a number of biblical translations.<ref>For example, NIV, NLT, ESV, Holman, and NET</ref>
=== Jaresiah === ''See [[Jaareshiah]].''
===Jarha=== '''Jarha''' was an Egyptian slave of Sheshan who was married to Sheshan's daughter according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/1 Chronicles#Chapter 2|1 Chronicles 2:34–35]].
=== Jarah === ''See [[Jehoaddah]].''
=== Jasiel === ''See [[Jaasiel]].''
=== Jathniel === '''Jathniel''' is a minor biblical figure who appears only in 1 Chronicles 26:2, in a list of Korahite porters.<ref name="cb jathniel">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jathniel|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jaziz === '''Jaziz''' the [[Hagrite]], according to 1 Chronicles 27:31, was in charge of king [[David]]'s flocks of sheep and goats.
=== Jeatherai === ''See [[Ethni]].''
=== Jecamiah === ''See [[Jekamiah]].''
===Jecholiah=== '''Jecholiah''' (Hebrew: יכליהו, ''yekhalyahu'') of Jerusalem was the wife of the King of Judah, Amaziah, and the mother of King Azariah.<ref>2 Kings 15:2</ref> Depending on translation used, her name may also be spelled '''Jechiliah,''' '''Jecoliah,''' or '''Jekoliah.'''
=== Jediael === There are three individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]] named Jediael.<ref name="cb jediael">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jediael|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * Jediael son of Shimri is listed as one of [[David]]'s warriors in 1 Chronicles 11:45. * Jediael, a man from the [[Tribe of Manasseh]], appears in a list of warriors said to have deserted [[David]] when he went to [[Ziklag]].<ref>1 Chronicles 12:20</ref> * Jediael son of Meshelemiah appears in a list of Korahite porters in the time of David.<ref>1 Chronicles 26:2</ref>
===Jeezer=== '''Jeezer''' was a son of [[Gilead]] of the [[Tribe of Manasseh]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:30]].
=== Jehallelel === '''Jehallelel''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] '''Jehaleleel''' or '''Jehalelel''') is the name of two individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jehallelel">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jehallelel|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly CheyneA }}</ref> * A Jehallelel appears in 1 Chronicles 4:16, in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Judah]]. * Another Jehallelel appears in a list of Levites in 2 Chronicles 29:12.
=== Jehdeiah === '''Jehdeiah''' is the name of two individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jehdeiah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jehdeiah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * A Levite mentioned in 1 Chronicles 24:20. * Jehdeiah the Meronothite, who according to 1 Chronicles 27:30 was in charge of king [[David]]'s donkeys.
=== Jehiah === '''Jehiah''' is a figure who is only mentioned once in the Bible, in 1 Chronicles 15:24, which describes him as a gatekeeper for the [[Ark of the Covenant]] in the time of [[David]].<ref name="cb jehiah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jehiah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jehiel === ''This entry contains close paraphrases and borrowing of wording found in entries entitled "Jehiel" the Encyclopaedia Biblica, a work that is now in the public domain.''
'''Jehiel''' is the name of fourteen figures in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jehiel">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jehiel|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
For eleven of these the English spelling "Jehiel" reflects the Hebrew name יחיאל:<ref name="cb jehiel" /> * A Levite musician in the time of David (1 Chronicles 15:18, 20; 16:5). * The leader of a family of Gershonite Levities in the time of David (1 Chronicles 23:8; 29:8). * Jehiel the son of Hachmoni, who was with David's sons (1 Chronicles 27:32). * Jehiel the son of king Jehoshaphat (2 Chronicles 21:2). * A Hemanite Levite in the time of Hezekiah, called '''Jehuel''' in the Revised Version (2 Chronicles 29:14). * A Levitical or priestly oversees of the temple in the time of Hezekiah (2 Chronicles 31:13). * A person referred to as "ruler of the house of God" in the time of Josiah (2 Chronicles 35:8). * The father of Obadiah in a post-exilic list of kin groups (Ezra 8:9). * The father of Shechaniah (Ezra 10:2). * Jehiel the son of Harim, a priest (Ezra 10:21). * Jehiel the son of Elam, a layman (Ezra 10:26).
For the other three, the name Jehiel (or '''Jeiel''') reflects the Hebrew spelling יעיאל. * One of the sons of Elam (Ezra 10:2). * A Gibeonite described as the "father of Gibeon" in 1 Chronicles 9:35. * A son of Hothan the Aroerite, who along with his brother Shama was listed as one of [[David's Mighty Warriors]] in 1 Chronicles 11:44.
=== Jehizkiah === '''Jehizkiah''' son of Shallum is mentioned in a list of Ephraimite leaders who, according to 2 Chronicles 28, intervened along with the prophet Oded to prevent the enslavement of 200,000 people from the [[Kingdom of Judah]] during the time of the king [[Ahaz]].<ref>Jehizkiah appears in the narrative in 2 Chronicles 28:12</ref>
=== Jehoaddah === '''Joehoaddah''' (or '''Jehoadah,''' '''Jarah''') was one of the descendants of King [[Saul]], according to 1 Chronicles 8:33–36. In 1 Chronicles 9:42, which contains a copy of the same genealogy of Saul, his name is given as "Jarah."<ref name="cb jehoadah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jehoadah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Jehoaddan=== '''Jehoaddan''' (Hebrew: יהועדן, Yehōaddān; "YHWH delights") was a native of Jerusalem, the wife of King Joash of Judah, and mother of his successor, King Amaziah. II Kings 14:2
===Jehoiada=== '''Jehoiada''' (Hebrew: יהוידע,''Yehoyada'' "The LORD Knows"<ref>Strong's</ref>) was the name of at least three people in the Hebrew Bible: * Jehoiada, a priest during the reigns of Ahaziah, Athaliah, and Joash (q.v.) * Jehoiada, father of Benaiah (cf. Benaiah) * Jehoiada, a priest in the time of Jeremiah (Jeremiah 29:26)
===Jehoshaphat=== '''Jehoshaphat''' (Hebrew: יהושפט, ''yehoshaphat,'' God Judges), son of Paruah, was one of King Solomon's twelve regional administrators: his jurisdiction was Issachar (I Kings 4:17).
'''Jehosphaphat''', son of Ahilud, was King Solomon's recorder (I Kings 4:3).
===Jehozabad=== '''Jehozabad''' (Hebrew: יהוזבד, ''yehozabad'') is the name of three figures in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jehozabad">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jehozabad|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * Jehozabad son of Shomer was one of the assassinators of King Joash of Judah. II Kings 12:21. "This person is called ''Zabad'', in 2 Chron. xxiv.26..." <ref name="Adam Clarke">{{cite book|last=Clarke|first=Adam|title=Commentary and Critical Notes|year=1831|publisher=J. Emory and B. Waugh|location=New York}}</ref> * Jehozabad, according 2 Chronicles 17:18, was a leader of 180,000 Benjamite warriors in the time of king [[Jehoshaphat]]. * Jehozabad is listed as one of the sons of Obed-edom according to 1 Chronicles 26:4.
=== Jehubbah === '''Jehubbah''' (or '''Hubbah''') is the name of an individual who appears in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Asher]]. His name depends on which variant reading (see [[Qere and Ketiv]]) of the [[Masoretic Text]] one follows: the Ketiv reads ''yhbh'' ("Jehubbah") the Qere reads ''whbh'' ("and Hubbah").<ref name="cb jehubbah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=TITLE|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
===Jehudi=== '''Jehudi''' (Hebrew יהודי "Judahite") "the son of Nethaniah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Cushi" (Jeremiah 36:14) was one of the delegates the princes sent to fetch Baruch, Jeremiah's scribe, to read his scroll.
=== Jehudijah === '''Jehudijah''' (Hebrew ''hayyehudiyyah'') is, in the [[King James Version]], the name of a wife of Mered, and the mother of several of his children.<ref name="cb jehudijah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jehudijah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> The Jewish Publication Society Bible of 1917 calls her "Hajehudijah." However, the [[Revised Version]] simply treats the word as a noun: "the Jewess."<ref name="cb jehudijah" /> The meaning of the passage is difficult due to several scribal errors.<ref name="cb jehudijah" />
=== Jehush === ''See [[Jeush]].''
===Jeiel=== '''Jeiel''' is the name of ten individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jeiel">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jeiel|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref> * Jeiel, according to 1 Chronicles 5:7, was a leader in the [[Tribe of Reuben]]. * Jeiel, referred to as the "father of [[Gibeon (ancient city)|Gibeon]]", was an ancestor of [[King Saul]].<ref>({{bibleverse|1|Chronicles|9:35–39|NIV}})</ref> The [[King James Version]] calls him "Jehiel."<ref name="cb jeiel" /> This figure's name is affected by variant readings preserved through the [[Qere and Ketiv]] system in the [[Masoretic Text]]: the Ketiv calls him "Jeuel," while the Qere calls him "Jeiel."<ref name="cb jeiel" /> * Jeiel son of Hotham the Aroerite is listed as one of David's warriors in 1 Chronicles 11:44. The King James Version calls him "Jehiel." This figure's name is affected by variant readings preserved through the [[Qere and Ketiv]] system in the [[Masoretic Text]]: the Ketiv calls him "Jeuel," while the Qere calls him "Jeiel."<ref name="cb jeiel" /> * A Jeiel is mentioned in passing in a list of gatekeepers for the [[Ark of the Covenant]] in 1 Chronicles 15:18. * A Jeiel is listed as one of the ancestors of a Levite named Jahaziel in 2 Chronicles 20:14. * A Jeiel was one of the scribes of [[Uzziah]] according to 2 Chronicles 26:11. This figure's name is affected by variant readings preserved through the [[Qere and Ketiv]] system in the [[Masoretic Text]]: the Ketiv calls him "Jeuel," while the Qere calls him "Jeiel."<ref name="cb jeiel" /> * A Jeiel is recorded as a Levite in the time of [[Hezekiah]]. This figure's name is affected by variant readings preserved through the [[Qere and Ketiv]] system in the [[Masoretic Text]]: the Ketiv calls him "Jeuel," while the Qere calls him "Jeiel."<ref name="cb jeiel" /> The [[Revised Version]] calls him Jeuel, following the Ketiv.<ref name="cb jeiel" /> * A Jeiel is recorded as a leader in the [[Tribe of Levi]] in time of [[Uzziah]] according to 2 Chronicles 35:9. * In a list of returnees to [[Yehud Medinata]] after the end of the [[Babylonian captivity]], a Jeiel is recorded as being the head of a group of relatives according to Ezra 8:13. The [[Revised Version]] calls him Jeuel. * A Jeiel, of the "descendants of Nebo," is listed as one of the people opposing marriage to foreign women in the time of [[Nehemiah]].<ref>Ezra 10:43</ref>
=== Jekameam === '''Jekameam''' son of Hebron is mentioned in passing in two genealogical passages.<ref>1 Chronicles 23:19, 24:23.</ref>
=== Jekamiah === '''Jekamiah''' ([[King James Version|KJV]] spelling '''Jecamiah''') is the name of two individuals in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jekamiah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jekamiah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * Jekamiah son of Shallum, son of Sismai, son of Eleasah, son of Helez, son of Azariah, son of Jehu, son of Obed, son of Ephlal, son of Zabad, son of Nathan, son of Attai, son of Jarha, the son-in-law and slave of Sheshan, son of Ishi, son of Appaim, son of Nadab, son of Shammai, son of Onam, son of Jerahmeel, the alleged ancestor of the [[Jerahmeel]]ites.<ref>1 Chronicles 2</ref> * Jekamiah, a son of [[Jeconiah]], the last king of [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]], who was taken captive by the [[Babylonia]]ns.<ref>1 Chronicles 3:18</ref>
=== Jekoliah === ''See [[Jecholiah]].''
=== Jekuthiel === '''Jekuthiel''', father of Zanoah, appears in 1 Chronicles 4:18, in a genealogical passage concerning the [[Tribe of Judah]].<ref>1 Chronicles 4:18</ref>
===Jemima=== '''Jemima''', meaning "Dove" was a daughter of [[Job (biblical figure)|Job]] according to Job 42:14.
===Jemuel=== '''Jemuel''' was a son of [[Simeon (Hebrew Bible)|Simeon]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 46|Genesis 46:10]], [[:s:Bible (King James)/Exodus#Chapter 6|Exodus 6:15]], and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:12]]. He was one of the 70 souls to migrate to Egypt with Jacob.
===Jephunneh=== '''Jephunneh''' (יְפֻנֶּה) is a biblical name which means "for whom a way is prepared", and was the name of two biblical figures: * A descendant of [[Judah (son of Jacob)|Judah]], and father of [[Kenaz]] and [[Caleb]] the [[The Twelve Spies|spy]] or scout, who appears to have belonged to an Edomitish tribe called [[Kenezite]]s, from [[Kenaz]] their founder. See ([[Book of Numbers|Numbers]] 13:6 etc.; Num. 32:12 etc.; Josh 14:14 etc.; 1 Chr 4:15). * A descendant of [[Asher]], eldest of the three sons of [[Jether]] (1 [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]] 7:38).
===Jerah=== '''Jerah''' was a son of [[Joktan]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 10|Genesis 10:26]], [[:s:Bible (King James)/1 Chronicles#Chapter 1|1 Chronicles 1:20]].
=== Jeremai === '''Jeremai''', one of the "descendants of Hashum," is a figure who appears only in Ezra 10:33, where he is listed among the men who married foreign women.<ref name="cb jeremai">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jeremai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jeriah === ''See [[Jerijah]].''
=== Jerioth === '''Jerioth''' was a wife of [[Caleb]] according to 1 Chronicles 2:18.
=== Jeriel === '''Jeriel,''' son of Tola, son of [[Issachar]], is found in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Issachar]] in 1 Chronicles 7:2.
=== Jerijah === '''Jerijah''' (sometimes '''Jeriah''') is listed is one of the sons of Hebron in genealogical passages in 1 Chronicles 23:19, 24:23, 26:31.<ref name="cb jerijah">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jerijah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jerusha === '''Jerusha''' (or '''Jerushah''') the daughter of Zadok was, according to the 2 Kings 15:33 and 2 Chronicles 27:1, the mother of king [[Jotham of Judah]].
===Jesbi=== See [[List of minor biblical figures, A-K#Ishbi-benob|Ishbi-benob]]
===Jeshaiah=== '''Jeshaiah''' may refer to multiple figures in the Bible: # A descendant of David, the father of [[Rephaiah]], and the son of [[Hananiah, son of Zerubbabel|Hananiah]] in [[:s:Bible (King James)/1 Chronicles#Chapter 3|1 Chronicles 3:21]]. # One of eight sons of Jeduthun in [[:s:Bible (King James)/1 Chronicles#Chapter 25|1 Chronicles 25:3]]. # For the man in 1 Chronicles 24 and 26 who is sometimes called Jeshaiah, see [[Jesiah]].
=== Jesher === '''Jesher''' the son of [[Caleb]] is mentioned only in 1 Chronicles 2:18.
=== Jeshishai === '''Jeshishai''' is a figure mentioned only once, in passing, in a genealogy of Gad.<ref>1 Chronicles 5:14</ref><ref name="cb jeshishai">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jeshishai|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref>
=== Jeshohaiah === '''Jeshohaiah''' appears in a list of names of [[Tribe of Simeon|Simeonites]]. According to [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]] these Simeonites took pasture-land from descendants of Ham and the Meunim during the time of king Hezekiah.<ref name="ReferenceB">The narrative is recorded in 1 Chronicles 4:34–43, with Jeshohaiah himself mentioned in verse 36.</ref> According to Thomas Kelly Cheyne, the name is a corruption of Maaseiah.<ref name="cb jeshohaiah">{{cite book |author=Thomas Kelly Cheyne |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jeshohaiah|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Thomas Kelly Cheyne }}</ref>
=== Jesimiel === '''Jesimiel''' appears in a list of names of [[Tribe of Simeon|Simeonites]]. According to [[Books of Chronicles|Chronicles]] these Simeonites took pasture-land from descendants of Ham and the Meunim during the time of king Hezekiah.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> According to Thomas Kelly Cheyne, the name is a corruption of Maaseel.<ref name="cb jeshohaiah"/>
=== Jesui === ''See [[Ishvi]].''
=== Jeuel === '''Jeuel''' son of Zerah appears in a list of people living in Jerusalem after the end of the [[Babylonian exile]]. For four other individuals who are sometimes called "Jeuel" and sometimes "Jeiel," see [[Jeiel]].
=== Jeush === '''Jeush''' is the name of four or five individuals mentioned in the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="cb jeush">{{cite book |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Jeush|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= }}</ref> * Jeush son of Esau.<ref>Genesis 36:5, 14, 18; 1 Chronicles 1:35.</ref> A variant manuscript reading, known as [[Qere and Ketiv|Ketiv]], calls him '''Jeish.'''<ref name="cb jeush" /> * Jeush son of Bilhan, son of Jediael, the son of [[Benjamin]], mentioned in a genealogy which describes the people of the [[Tribe of Benjamin]].<ref name="1 Chronicles 7:10"/> * Jeush son of Eshek, who is mentioned in a genealogy of the Tribe of Benjamin.<ref name="1 Chronicles 8:39"/> According to the ''Encyclopaedia Biblica,'' this is likely a reference to the same person called Jeush son of Bilhan. The [[King James Version]] calls him '''Jehush.''' * Jeush son of Shimei represented a division of Levites according to 1 Chronicles 23:10–11. * Jeush son of king [[Rehoboam]].<ref>2 Chronicles 11:19</ref>
===Jezebel=== '''Jezebel''' was a [[false prophet]]ess whom Jesus warned the church in [[Thyatira]] not to follow. She encouraged her followers to be promiscuous and to eat food sacrificed to idols. Jesus gave her a chance to repent of her sins, but she did not; thus, Jesus promised to punish her (see {{bibleref||Revelation|2:20–23}}).
===Jezer=== '''Jezer''' was a son of [[Naphtali]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 46|Genesis 46:24]] and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:49]]. He was one of the 70 persons to migrate to Egypt with Jacob. According to Numbers he was the progenitor of the Jezerites.
=== Jeziah === ''See [[Izziah]].''
=== Jezoar === ''See [[List of minor biblical figures, A–K#Izhar|Izhar]].''
=== Jezrahiah === ''See [[Izrahiah]]''.
===Jezreel=== One of the sons of the father of [[Etam (biblical figure)|Etam]] according to {{bibleverse|1|Chronicles|4:3|NKJV}}
=== Jibsam === ''See [[Ibsam]].''
===Jidlaph=== '''Jidlaph''' was the son of [[Nahor, son of Terah|Nahor]] and [[Milcah]] ({{bibleverse-lb||Genesis|22:22|HE}}).
===Jimnah=== '''Jimnah''' or '''Jimna''' was a son of [[Asher]] according to [[:s:Bible (King James)/Genesis#Chapter 46|Genesis 46:17]] and [[:s:Bible (King James)/Numbers#Chapter 26|Numbers 26:44]]. He was one of the 70 souls to migrate to Egypt with Jacob.
===Jishui=== '''Jishui''' was the second son of [[King Saul]], mentioned in Saul's genealogy in {{bibleverse|1|Samuel|14:49|NKJV}}. He is called Abinadab in 1 Chronicles 8:33 and 9:39.
=== Joahaz === ''For either of the biblical kings names Jehoahaz or Joahaz, see [[Jehoahaz of Israel]] or [[Jehoahaz of Judah]].''
'''Joahaz''', according 2 Chronicles 34:8, was the name of the father of [[Josiah]]'s scribe Joah.
===Joash=== ''This entry is about the four minor biblical characters named Joash. For the kings named Joash or Jehoash, see [[Jehoash of Israel]] and [[Jehoash of Judah]].''
'''Joash,''' an abbreviated name of '''Jehoash,''' is the name of several figures in the [[Hebrew Bible]]. * Joash, an [[Abiezrite]] of the [[Tribe of Manasseh]], was the father of [[Gideon]] according to [[Book of Judges|Judges]] 6–8.<ref>[[:s:Bible (King James)/Judges#Chapter 6|Judges 6–8]]</ref> His family was poor and lived in [[Ophrah]]. After Gideon tore down the altar of [[Baal]] and cut down the grove, the men of Ophrah sought to kill Gideon. Joash stood against them, saying, "He that will plead for [Baal], let him be put to death whilst it is yet morning: if he be a god, let him plead for himself, because one hath cast down his altar." * A Joash is described as "the king's son" in the time of [[Ahab]]. According to Stanley Arthur Cook, it is uncertain whether he was the son of king Ahab, or whether "king's son" was a title used high officers.<ref name="cb joash">{{cite book |author=Stanley Arthur Cook |editor1=T. K. Cheyne|editor2=J. Sutherland Black|date=1901|origyear=1899 |chapter=Joash|title=Encyclopaedia Biblica: A Critical Dictionary of the Literary, Political, and Religious History, the Archaeology, Geography, and Natural History of the Bible |url=https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib02cheyuoft |volume=2, E–K|location=New York |publisher=The Macmillan Company |isbn= |author-link=Stanley Arthur Cook }}</ref> * Joash is described as one of the sons of Shelah son of [[Judah (son of Jacob)]] in a genealogy of the [[Tribe of Judah]].<ref>1 Chronicles 4:22</ref> * A Joash is named as one of the Benjamite warriors to came to the aid of [[David]] when he went to [[Ziklag]].<ref>1 Chronicles 12:3</ref>
